Virtual and Augmented Reality in Anatomy Education: Exploring New Horizons

Author: Nikas, Dimitrios1; Toumanidou, Margarita2; Vergados, Dimitrios3; Mariolis-Sapsakos, Theodoros4; Tsolis, Nikolaos3; Filippou, Dimitrios5; Troupis, Theodoros5; Koumenis, Andreas1; Kalemikerakis, Ioannis6; Karakatsanis, Stamatis7; Dimakakos, Evangelos81 Laboratory of Anatomy, Advanced Anatomical Applications, Artificial Intelligence, and Experimental Surgical Research (AAAAAIES Lab), Athens, Greece; Nursing School, University of Athens, Greece2 Center of Diagnosis, Prevention, and Treatment of Lymphedema-Lymphatic Diseases of Metropolitan Hospital, Athens, Greece ritatoum89@gmail.com3 University of Piraeus, Greece4 Laboratory of Anatomy, Advanced Anatomical Applications, Artificial Intelligence, and Experimental Surgical Research (AAAAAIES Lab), Athens, Greece; National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Greece; Faculty of Nursing, University of Athens, Greece5 Department of Anatomy, Faculty of Medicine, School of Health Sciences, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Greece6 Laboratory of Nursing Rehabilitation of the Chronically Ill (NRCILab), Community Nursing Department, Nursing School, University of West Attica, Greece7 Third Department of Internal Medicine, Sotiria General Hospital for Chest Diseases, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Greece8 Center of Diagnosis, Prevention, and Treatment of Lymphedema-Lymphatic Diseases of Metropolitan Hospital, Athens, Greece; Anatomy-Physiology, Nursing School, University of West Attica, Greece edimakakos@yahoo.gr

Publication info: Nikas, Dimitrios; Toumanidou, Margarita; Vergados, Dimitrios; Mariolis-Sapsakos, Theodoros; Tsolis, Nikolaos; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/virtual-augmented-reality-anatomy-education/docview/3271569829/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This review explores how virtual and augmented reality technologies are transforming medical education and clinical practice, particularly in anatomy instruction. Virtual and augmented reality technologies are reshaping our perception and interaction with anatomical structures. Their integration into medical practice has introduced opportunities in diagnostics, surgical training, rehabilitation, and patient education. With the increasing number of U.S. Food and Drug Administration approvals, these technologies offer a transformative shift in the teaching and practice of medicine. Virtual environments facilitate detailed anatomical visualization, offering students and trainees immersive and interactive experiences. This paper highlights the role of these technologies in enhancing educational methods, improving knowledge retention, and overcoming traditional limitations, such as the scarcity of cadavers. CONCLUSION: Virtual and augmented reality offer novel educational tools in the health sciences, providing cost-effective, accessible, and innovative approaches to anatomy education and clinical application. Further research is required to elucidate the benefits of these technologies in the education and training of medical students.This review explores how virtual and augmented reality technologies are transforming medical education and clinical practice, particularly in anatomy instruction. Virtual and augmented reality technologies are reshaping our perception and interaction with anatomical structures. Their integration into medical practice has introduced opportunities in diagnostics, surgical training, rehabilitation, and patient education. With the increasing number of U.S. Food and Drug Administration approvals, these technologies offer a transformative shift in the teaching and practice of medicine. Virtual environments facilitate detailed anatomical visualization, offering students and trainees immersive and interactive experiences. This paper highlights the role of these technologies in enhancing educational methods, improving knowledge retention, and overcoming traditional limitations, such as the scarcity of cadavers. CONCLUSION: Virtual and augmented reality offer novel educational tools in the health sciences, providing cost-effective, accessible, and innovative approaches to anatomy education and clinical application. Further research is required to elucidate the benefits of these technologies in the education and training of medical students.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Dimitrios&amp;aulast=Nikas&amp;atitle=Virtual+and+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+Education%3A+Exploring+New+Horizons&amp;stitle=Acta+medica+academica&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.5644%2Fama2006-124.481&amp;title=Virtual+and+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+Education%3A+Exploring+New+Horizons&amp;volume=54&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Dimitrios&amp;aulast=Nikas&amp;atitle=Virtual+and+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+Education%3A+Exploring+New+Horizons&amp;stitle=Acta+medica+academica&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.5644%2Fama2006-124.481&amp;title=Virtual+and+Augmented+Reality+in+Anatomy+Education%3A+Exploring+New+Horizons&amp;volume=54&amp;issue=2&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

The Impact and Importance of Serious Games in Maritime Education: An Empirical Application

Author: Christodoulou Raftis, Charilaos1; van Hassel, Edwin1; Nanway Boukani, Loghman11 U of Antwerp

Publication info: Christodoulou Raftis, Charilaos; van Hassel, Edwin; Nanway Boukani, Loghman. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/impact-importance-serious-games-maritime/docview/3263101210/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Gamification and serious gaming have emerged as alternative approaches in learning and decision-making across various domains. In maritime education and the inland waterways sector, where traditional methods may fall short in engaging learners effectively, the development of tailored serious games presents a unique opportunity. This research assesses the educational value of a serious game designed for the maritime industry and inland waterways. The game was developed through a systematic process involving a literature review, stakeholder consultations, and expert input. The methodology included iterative design, user testing, and feedback collection from participants across various sectors. The game features tasks simulating port operations, equipment handling, and inland navigation, followed by quizzes to reinforce learning. Data analysis was performed to evaluate user engagement, knowledge retention, and satisfaction levels. Evaluation results indicate high user engagement, improved knowledge retention, and participant satisfaction. This research underlines the potential of serious games in maritime education, offering innovative solutions to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and practical application, thereby maximizing learning outcomes and preparing individuals comprehensively for the challenges of the maritime industry and inland waterways sector.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Charilaos&amp;aulast=Christodoulou+Raftis&amp;atitle=The+Impact+and+Importance+of+Serious+Games+in+Maritime+Education%3A+An+Empirical+Application&amp;stitle=Maritime+Policy+and+Management&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F03088839.2024.2442603&amp;title=The+Impact+and+Importance+of+Serious+Games+in+Maritime+Education%3A+An+Empirical+Application&amp;volume=52&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=985&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Outcomes of a Medical Student Elective in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry: A Pilot Study

Author: Grant, Larrilyn1    ; Singh, Lexi1; Fristad, Mary A2    ; Barbee, Jeff3    ; Kerlek, Anna2    1 Department of Psychiatry, Wright State University Boonshoft School of Medicine, Dayton, OH USA2 Division of Child & Fa mily Psychiatry, Nationwide Children's Hospital, Columbus, OH USA; Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Health, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH USA3 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Health, The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Columbus, OH USA

Publication info: Grant, Larrilyn; Singh, Lexi; Fristad, Mary A; Barbee, Jeff; Kerlek, Anna. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/outcomes-medical-student-elective-child/docview/3263074815/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: A majority of youth with mental health concerns lack access to psychiatric care, often relying on general practitioners who may feel unprepared. Enhancing medical education in child psychiatry is crucial. This study evaluated changes in medical students' perspectives after participating in an interactive Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (CAP) elective. Significant improvements were found in students' comfort assessing suicidal thoughts, evaluating mental health diagnoses, and understanding biopsychosocial factors. The findings suggest that participation in CAP electives may boost student confidence in handling youth mental health issues, highlighting the need for further studies on knowledge retention and career impact.A majority of youth with mental health concerns lack access to psychiatric care, often relying on general practitioners who may feel unprepared. Enhancing medical education in child psychiatry is crucial. This study evaluated changes in medical students' perspectives after participating in an interactive Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (CAP) elective. Significant improvements were found in students' comfort assessing suicidal thoughts, evaluating mental health diagnoses, and understanding biopsychosocial factors. The findings suggest that participation in CAP electives may boost student confidence in handling youth mental health issues, highlighting the need for further studies on knowledge retention and career impact.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Larrilyn&amp;aulast=Grant&amp;atitle=Outcomes+of+a+Medical+Student+Elective+in+Child+and+Adolescent+Psychiatry%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;stitle=Medical+science+educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02381-0&amp;title=Outcomes+of+a+Medical+Student+Elective+in+Child+and+Adolescent+Psychiatry%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Work-based Surface Anatomy Teaching Model: A Contextualized Method for Promoting Learning Competencies in Medical Curricula

Author: Bakar, Yasrul Izad Abu1    ; Yusoff, Muhamad Saiful Bahri2    ; Kasim, Fazlina3    ; Sulong, Husnaida Abdul Manan4    ; Hadie, Siti Nurma Hanim3    1 Department of Medical and Health Professionals Education, Faculty of Medicine, Medical Campus, Universiti Sultan Zainal Abidin, Kuala Terengganu, Terengganu Malaysia; Department of Medical Education, School of Medical Sciences, Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Kubang Kerian, Kota Bharu, Malaysia2 Department of Medical Education, School of Medical Sciences, Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Kubang Kerian, Kota Bharu, Malaysia3 Department of Anatomy, School of Medical Sciences, Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Kubang Kerian, Kota Bharu, Kelantan Malaysia4 Clinical Medicine Department, Advanced Medical and Dental Institute, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Bertam, Kepala Batas, Penang Malaysia

Publication info: Bakar, Yasrul Izad Abu; Yusoff, Muhamad Saiful Bahri; Kasim, Fazlina; Sulong, Husnaida Abdul Manan; Hadie, Siti Nurma Hanim. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/work-based-surface-anatomy-teaching-model/docview/3263074659/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Surface anatomy plays a crucial role in medical education, providing a foundation for the safe acquisition of physical examination and clinical skills among medical students. Despite its importance, surface anatomy education often receives insufficient emphasis in medical curricula, lacking robust empirical support for its effectiveness in higher education. This study addresses this gap by introducing a comprehensive Work-based Surface Anatomy Teaching (WSAT) model, shaped by insights from two scoping review findings. Rigorous expert ratings were employed to establish the model's content, response process, and internal validity. A small-scale randomized controlled trial involving 27 participants compared the WSAT instruction to routine surface anatomy instruction in a control group. Through pre- and post-teaching assessments, and follow-up sessions, the study measured knowledge retention, cognitive loads, learning engagement, and changes in learning competencies. Results revealed that the intervention group, receiving WSAT instruction, demonstrated significantly lower extraneous load, heightened self-perceived learning, and increased cognitive and physical engagement compared to the control group. Despite similar baseline surface competencies, the intervention group outperformed the control in acquiring cognitive, psychomotor, and affective competencies, as well as in retaining psychomotor skills and displaying professional behavior. While these findings are promising, future studies are necessary to assess the impact of WSAT instruction on student learning behaviors and organizational dynamics. A larger trial across multiple institutions will contribute valuable insights into the feasibility and applicability of the WSAT model in diverse demographic settings, ultimately enhancing medical education practices.Surface anatomy plays a crucial role in medical education, providing a foundation for the safe acquisition of physical examination and clinical skills among medical students. Despite its importance, surface anatomy education often receives insufficient emphasis in medical curricula, lacking robust empirical support for its effectiveness in higher education. This study addresses this gap by introducing a comprehensive Work-based Surface Anatomy Teaching (WSAT) model, shaped by insights from two scoping review findings. Rigorous expert ratings were employed to establish the model's content, response process, and internal validity. A small-scale randomized controlled trial involving 27 participants compared the WSAT instruction to routine surface anatomy instruction in a control group. Through pre- and post-teaching assessments, and follow-up sessions, the study measured knowledge retention, cognitive loads, learning engagement, and changes in learning competencies. Results revealed that the intervention group, receiving WSAT instruction, demonstrated significantly lower extraneous load, heightened self-perceived learning, and increased cognitive and physical engagement compared to the control group. Despite similar baseline surface competencies, the intervention group outperformed the control in acquiring cognitive, psychomotor, and affective competencies, as well as in retaining psychomotor skills and displaying professional behavior. While these findings are promising, future studies are necessary to assess the impact of WSAT instruction on student learning behaviors and organizational dynamics. A larger trial across multiple institutions will contribute valuable insights into the feasibility and applicability of the WSAT model in diverse demographic settings, ultimately enhancing medical education practices.The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1007/s40670-025-02385-w. Supplementary Information The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1007/s40670-025-02385-w.

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yasrul+Izad&amp;aulast=Bakar&amp;atitle=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;stitle=Medical+science+educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02385-w&amp;title=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Empowering Early Learners: Unveiling the “Play and Learn” Mobile Adventure for Little Explorers

Author: Jamil Abedalrahim Jamil Alsayaydeh    ; Bacarra, Rex    ; Sivalinggam, Yalan    ; Zaiko, Tetiana    ; Herawan, Safarudin Gazali    

Publication info: Jamil Abedalrahim Jamil Alsayaydeh; Bacarra, Rex; Sivalinggam, Yalan; Zaiko, Tetiana; Herawan, Safarudin Gazali. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/empowering-early-learners-unveiling-play-learn/docview/3262160781/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: In this mixed‑methods study, 73 preschoolers from three schools participated in pre‑test/post‑test assessments and user satisfaction surveys to evaluate the "Play and Learn" mobile e‑learning application for foundational learning of alphabets, numbers, and shapes in children aged 3–6 years. The app’s multimedia elements—animations, music, and interactive quizzes—were tailored to young learners’ cognitive abilities to ensure smooth navigation and sustained attention. Results showed significant gains across all three schools, with perfect-score rates rising from 79% pre‑test to 93% post‑test, and a 93% satisfaction rate for engagement and design effectiveness. These findings demonstrate how educational technology, multimedia learning, and adaptive design can bridge gaps in early childhood education by enhancing knowledge retention and holistic development. In conclusion, "Play and Learn" offers an innovative, accessible, and enjoyable mobile learning solution for preschoolers and provides valuable insights for future e‑learning technologies.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Jamil+Abedalrahim+Jamil+Alsayaydeh&amp;atitle=Empowering+Early+Learners%3A+Unveiling+the+%26ldquo%3BPlay+and+Learn%26rdquo%3B+Mobile+Adventure+for+Little+Explorers&amp;stitle=Ingenierie+des+Systemes+d%27Information&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.18280%2Fisi.300804&amp;title=Empowering+Early+Learners%3A+Unveiling+the+%E2%80%9CPlay+and+Learn%E2%80%9D+Mobile+Adventure+for+Little+Explorers&amp;volume=30&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1975&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Work-based Surface Anatomy Teaching Model: A Contextualized Method for Promoting Learning Competencies in Medical Curricula

Author: Bakar, Yasrul Izad Abu1    ; Yusoff, Muhamad Saiful Bahri2    ; Kasim, Fazlina3    ; Sulong, Husnaida Abdul Manan4    ; Hadie, Siti Nurma Hanim3    1 Universiti Sultan Zainal Abidin, Department of Medical and Health Professionals Education, Faculty of Medicine, Medical Campus, Kuala Terengganu, Malaysia (GRID:grid.449643.8) (ISNI:0000 0000 9358 3479); Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Department of Medical Education, School of Medical Sciences, Kota Bharu, Malaysia (GRID:grid.11875.3a) (ISNI:0000 0001 2294 3534)2 Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Department of Medical Education, School of Medical Sciences, Kota Bharu, Malaysia (GRID:grid.11875.3a) (ISNI:0000 0001 2294 3534)3 Health Campus, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Department of Anatomy, School of Medical Sciences, Kota Bharu, Malaysia (GRID:grid.11875.3a) (ISNI:0000 0001 2294 3534)4 Advanced Medical and Dental Institute, Universiti Sains Malaysia, Clinical Medicine Department, Bertam, Kepala Batas, Malaysia (GRID:grid.11875.3a) (ISNI:0000 0001 2294 3534)

Publication info: Bakar, Yasrul Izad Abu; Yusoff, Muhamad Saiful Bahri; Kasim, Fazlina; Sulong, Husnaida Abdul Manan; Hadie, Siti Nurma Hanim. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/work-based-surface-anatomy-teaching-model/docview/3261967587/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Surface anatomy plays a crucial role in medical education, providing a foundation for the safe acquisition of physical examination and clinical skills among medical students. Despite its importance, surface anatomy education often receives insufficient emphasis in medical curricula, lacking robust empirical support for its effectiveness in higher education. This study addresses this gap by introducing a comprehensive Work-based Surface Anatomy Teaching (WSAT) model, shaped by insights from two scoping review findings. Rigorous expert ratings were employed to establish the model’s content, response process, and internal validity. A small-scale randomized controlled trial involving 27 participants compared the WSAT instruction to routine surface anatomy instruction in a control group. Through pre- and post-teaching assessments, and follow-up sessions, the study measured knowledge retention, cognitive loads, learning engagement, and changes in learning competencies. Results revealed that the intervention group, receiving WSAT instruction, demonstrated significantly lower extraneous load, heightened self-perceived learning, and increased cognitive and physical engagement compared to the control group. Despite similar baseline surface competencies, the intervention group outperformed the control in acquiring cognitive, psychomotor, and affective competencies, as well as in retaining psychomotor skills and displaying professional behavior. While these findings are promising, future studies are necessary to assess the impact of WSAT instruction on student learning behaviors and organizational dynamics. A larger trial across multiple institutions will contribute valuable insights into the feasibility and applicability of the WSAT model in diverse demographic settings, ultimately enhancing medical education practices.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yasrul+Izad&amp;aulast=Bakar&amp;atitle=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;stitle=Medical+Science+Educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02385-w&amp;title=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1959&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yasrul+Izad&amp;aulast=Bakar&amp;atitle=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;stitle=Medical+Science+Educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02385-w&amp;title=Work-based+Surface+Anatomy+Teaching+Model%3A+A+Contextualized+Method+for+Promoting+Learning+Competencies+in+Medical+Curricula&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1959&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

ERIC Subject: Learning Modalities; Critical Thinking; Integrated Curriculum; Competence; Educational Resources; Experiential Learning; Influence of Technology; Learning Processes; Medical Education; Learning Theories; Learning Experience; Group Activities; Instructional Materials; Cooperative Learning; Communication Skills; Anatomy; Medical Evaluation; Blended Learning; Instructional Design; Instructional Effectiveness; Evidence Based Practice; Educational Environment; Lifelong Learning; Learner Engagement; Educational Strategies

Outcomes of a Medical Student Elective in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry: A Pilot Study

Author: Grant, Larrilyn1    ; Singh, Lexi1; Fristad, Mary A.2    ; Barbee, Jeff3    ; Kerlek, Anna2    1 Wright State University Boonshoft School of Medicine, Department of Psychiatry, Dayton, USA (GRID:grid.268333.f) (ISNI:0000 0004 1936 7937)2 Nationwide Children’s Hospital, Division of Child & Family Psychiatry, Columbus, USA (GRID:grid.240344.5) (ISNI:0000 0004 0392 3476); The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Health, Columbus, USA (GRID:grid.261331.4) (ISNI:0000 0001 2285 7943)3 The Ohio State University College of Medicine, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Health, Columbus, USA (GRID:grid.261331.4) (ISNI:0000 0001 2285 7943)

Publication info: Grant, Larrilyn; Singh, Lexi; Fristad, Mary A; Barbee, Jeff; Kerlek, Anna. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/outcomes-medical-student-elective-child/docview/3261967582/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: A majority of youth with mental health concerns lack access to psychiatric care, often relying on general practitioners who may feel unprepared. Enhancing medical education in child psychiatry is crucial. This study evaluated changes in medical students’ perspectives after participating in an interactive Child and Adolescent Psychiatry (CAP) elective. Significant improvements were found in students’ comfort assessing suicidal thoughts, evaluating mental health diagnoses, and understanding biopsychosocial factors. The findings suggest that participation in CAP electives may boost student confidence in handling youth mental health issues, highlighting the need for further studies on knowledge retention and career impact.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Larrilyn&amp;aulast=Grant&amp;atitle=Outcomes+of+a+Medical+Student+Elective+in+Child+and+Adolescent+Psychiatry%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;stitle=Medical+Science+Educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02381-0&amp;title=Outcomes+of+a+Medical+Student+Elective+in+Child+and+Adolescent+Psychiatry%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1861&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Gamification-based teaching methods for pandemic and outbreak investigation training among healthcare professionals and students: A systematic review

Author: Krishnamoorthy, Yuvaraj1; Govindan, Dhanajayan2; Karunakaran, Monica3; Parveen, Muneera1; Poul, Afrith John1; Manohar, Anaswara1; Rajendran, Gunaseelan41 Evidence Synthesis Unit, Partnership for Research, Opportunities, Planning, Upskilling and Leadership (PROPUL) Evidence LLP, Chennai, India yuvaraj@propulevidence.org2 Department of Community Medicine, ESIC Medical College and Hospital, India3 Department of Anaesthesiology, Sri Lalithambigai Medical College and Hospital, Chennai, India4 Department of Emergency Medicine, Aarupadai Veedu Medical College and Hospital, India

Publication info: Krishnamoorthy, Yuvaraj; Govindan, Dhanajayan; Karunakaran, Monica; Parveen, Muneera; Poul, Afrith John; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/gamification-based-teaching-methods-pandemic/docview/3251240504/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted urgent need for effective training in pandemic and outbreak management among healthcare professionals. Traditional teaching methods often lack the engagement required to prepare learners for real-world challenges. This systematic review evaluates effectiveness of gamification-based teaching methods in enhancing knowledge, skills, and engagement in pandemic preparedness education for healthcare professionals and students. Methods: Systematic search was conducted across PubMed, Scopus, Cochrane, Google Scholar, and ScienceDirect databases, identifying studies that employed gamification-based learning for pandemic management training. Studies were screened and selected based on predefined eligibility criteria, focusing on interventions targeting healthcare professionals or students. 12 studies were included, and narrative synthesis was conducted due to the heterogeneity in study designs, participant groups, and outcome measures. Results: Review found that gamification-based methods, such as serious games, e-learning modules, and simulations, improved knowledge retention, practical skills, and learner engagement compared to traditional teaching approaches. Participants reported high satisfaction and perceived usefulness of gamified interventions, with several studies demonstrating significant improvements in long-term knowledge retention and willingness to change behaviours related to infection control. However, variability in intervention design and outcome measures posed challenges for drawing generalized conclusions. Conclusion: Gamification-based teaching methods show promise in enhancing pandemic preparedness training among healthcare professionals. While these methods improve engagement and learning outcomes, further research is needed to explore long-term impacts, cost-effectiveness, and applicability in diverse educational settings. In addition, heterogeneity and methodological limitations of included studies underscore the need for more rigorous, high-quality research to validate these findings. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2025 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yuvaraj&amp;aulast=Krishnamoorthy&amp;atitle=Gamification-based+teaching+methods+for+pandemic+and+outbreak+investigation+training+among+healthcare+professionals+and+students%3A+A+systematic+review&amp;stitle=Simulation+%26+Gaming&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F10468781251338382&amp;title=Gamification-based+teaching+methods+for+pandemic+and+outbreak+investigation+training+among+healthcare+professionals+and+students%3A+A+systematic+review&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=392&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Yuvaraj&amp;aulast=Krishnamoorthy&amp;atitle=Gamification-based+teaching+methods+for+pandemic+and+outbreak+investigation+training+among+healthcare+professionals+and+students%3A+A+systematic+review&amp;stitle=Simulation+%26+Gaming&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F10468781251338382&amp;title=Gamification-based+teaching+methods+for+pandemic+and+outbreak+investigation+training+among+healthcare+professionals+and+students%3A+A+systematic+review&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=392&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Assessment of Long-Term Knowledge Retention in Children with Type 1 Diabetes and Their Families: A Pilot Study

Author: Carmon, Lior1    ; Hershkovitz, Eli1; Shaki, David1    ; Chechik, Tzila Gratzya2; Uritzki, Inna2; Gothelf, Itamar3; Walker, Dganit2; Loewenthal, Neta1; Nassar, Majd1; Haim, Alon1    1 Pediatrics Endocrinology Unit, Soroka University Medical Center, Beer-Sheva 8410501, Israel; Faculty of Health Sciences, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 8410501, Israel2 Pediatrics Endocrinology Unit, Soroka University Medical Center, Beer-Sheva 8410501, Israel3 Faculty of Health Sciences, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva 8410501, Israel

Publication info: Carmon, Lior; Hershkovitz, Eli; Shaki, David; Chechik, Tzila Gratzya; Uritzki, Inna; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/assessment-long-term-knowledge-retention-children/docview/3246413144/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The education process for newly diagnosed Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1D) patients and their families, primarily led by diabetes specialist nurses, is essential for gaining knowledge about the disease and its management. However, few assessment tools have been employed to evaluate long-term knowledge retention among T1D patients years after diagnosis. BACKGROUND The education process for newly diagnosed Type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1D) patients and their families, primarily led by diabetes specialist nurses, is essential for gaining knowledge about the disease and its management. However, few assessment tools have been employed to evaluate long-term knowledge retention among T1D patients years after diagnosis.We developed a 20-question test to assess the knowledge of patients and their families at the conclusion of the initial education process and again 6-12 months later. Demographic and clinical data were also collected. Statistical analyses included comparisons between the first and second test results, as well as evaluation of potential contributing factors. The internal consistency and construct validity of the questionnaire were evaluated. METHODS We developed a 20-question test to assess the knowledge of patients and their families at the conclusion of the initial education process and again 6-12 months later. Demographic and clinical data were also collected. Statistical analyses included comparisons between the first and second test results, as well as evaluation of potential contributing factors. The internal consistency and construct validity of the questionnaire were evaluated.Forty-four patients completed both assessments, with a median interval of 11.5 months between them. The average score on the first test was 88.6, which declined to 82.7 on the second assessment ( p < 0.001). In univariate analysis, factors positively associated with higher scores included Jewish ethnicity, lower HbA1c levels, and shorter hospitalization duration. Multivariate analysis revealed that parents had lower odds of experiencing a significant score decline compared to patients. Cronbach's alpha was 0.69, and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) identified eight components accounting for 67.1% of the total variance. RESULTS Forty-four patients completed both assessments, with a median interval of 11.5 months between them. The average score on the first test was 88.6, which declined to 82.7 on the second assessment (p < 0.001). In univariate analysis, factors positively associated with higher scores included Jewish ethnicity, lower HbA1c levels, and shorter hospitalization duration. Multivariate analysis revealed that parents had lower odds of experiencing a significant score decline compared to patients. Cronbach's alpha was 0.69, and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) identified eight components accounting for 67.1% of the total variance.Healthcare providers should consider offering re-education to patients and their families approximately one year after diagnosis, with particular attention to high-risk populations during the initial education phase. Further studies are needed to examine this tool's performance in larger cohorts. CONCLUSIONS Healthcare providers should consider offering re-education to patients and their families approximately one year after diagnosis, with particular attention to high-risk populations during the initial education phase. Further studies are needed to examine this tool's performance in larger cohorts.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Lior&amp;aulast=Carmon&amp;atitle=Assessment+of+Long-Term+Knowledge+Retention+in+Children+with+Type+1+Diabetes+and+Their+Families%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;stitle=Children+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fchildren12081016&amp;title=Assessment+of+Long-Term+Knowledge+Retention+in+Children+with+Type+1+Diabetes+and+Their+Families%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Lior&amp;aulast=Carmon&amp;atitle=Assessment+of+Long-Term+Knowledge+Retention+in+Children+with+Type+1+Diabetes+and+Their+Families%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;stitle=Children+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fchildren12081016&amp;title=Assessment+of+Long-Term+Knowledge+Retention+in+Children+with+Type+1+Diabetes+and+Their+Families%3A+A+Pilot+Study&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Assessment of Long-Term Knowledge Retention in Children with Type 1 Diabetes and Their Families: A Pilot Study

Correspondence author: Carmon, Lior  

Publication title: Children (Basel, Switzerland)

Journal abbreviation: Children (Basel)

Volume: 12

Connecting the pieces: Exploring the use of jigsaw puzzles in medical education to teach psychiatric disorders

Author: Mojahedi Mahya; Fatemehzahra, Ghafourifard1; Yeganeh, Khorasani Emad2; Eghbali Batool31 School of Medicine, Birjand University of Medical Sciences, Birjand, Iran2 Cellular and Molecular Research Center, Birjand University of Medical Sciences, Birjand, Iran3 Community Medicine Department, School of Medicine, Birjand University of Medical Sciences, Birjand, Iran

Publication info: Mojahedi Mahya; Fatemehzahra, Ghafourifard; Yeganeh, Khorasani Emad; Eghbali Batool. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/connecting-pieces-exploring-use-jigsaw-puzzles/docview/3244834618/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: BACKGROUND: Puzzle-solving has been recognized as an effective game-based educational strategy for active learning and can be used to learn complex topics such as psychiatric disorders. This research was designed to investigate the benefits of this technique on the learning, memorization, and satisfaction of general medical students in the clinical rotation of the psychiatry department and the role of related demographic factors. MATERIALS AND METHODS: Sixty-three medical students participated in this quasi-experimental study from January 2022 to February 2023. After completing a pre-test, the students engaged in three puzzle sets related to panic attacks, generalized anxiety, and social anxiety disorders based on the DSM-5 criteria. Following the completion of the puzzles, the students took a post-test and filled out a satisfaction questionnaire. Twenty days later, a follow-up test was conducted to assess knowledge retention. The data were then analyzed using SPSS-19 at a significance level of 0.05. Results: The post-test and follow-up test average scores were significantly higher than the pre-test ( P < 0.05), with a non-significant decrease in the follow-up ( P = 0.13). Additionally, the participants reported a high level of satisfaction. Conclusions: The puzzle-solving technique as an active strategy can have a very important role in the efficacy of the teaching-learning process, especially in complex subjects like psychiatry. The present study provides evidence that puzzle-solving training significantly improves the learning and memorization of psychiatric DSM criteria in medical students. The results of this study can be used to design a more active learning environment to improve learning outcomes in medical education.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Mojahedi+Mahya&amp;atitle=Connecting+the+pieces%3A+Exploring+the+use+of+jigsaw+puzzles+in+medical+education+to+teach+psychiatric+disorders&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Education+and+Health+Promotion&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fjehp.jehp_961_24&amp;title=Connecting+the+pieces%3A+Exploring+the+use+of+jigsaw+puzzles+in+medical+education+to+teach+psychiatric+disorders&amp;volume=14&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Mojahedi+Mahya&amp;atitle=Connecting+the+pieces%3A+Exploring+the+use+of+jigsaw+puzzles+in+medical+education+to+teach+psychiatric+disorders&amp;stitle=Journal+of+Education+and+Health+Promotion&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.4103%2Fjehp.jehp_961_24&amp;title=Connecting+the+pieces%3A+Exploring+the+use+of+jigsaw+puzzles+in+medical+education+to+teach+psychiatric+disorders&amp;volume=14&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

ERIC Subject: Retention (Psychology); Instructional Improvement; Anxiety Disorders; Pretesting; Student Satisfaction; Test Anxiety; Active Learning; Educational Methods; Teaching Methods; Learning Processes; Medical Education; Puzzles; Pretests Posttests; Medical Students; Student Participation; Mental Disorders; Psychiatry; Educational Strategies; Participant Satisfaction

Subject: Medical education; Mental disorders; Medical students; Acti ve learning

Impact of the Diabetes Conversation MapTM Program on Knowledge Retention, Self‐Management, and Self‐Efficacy Among Diabetic Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Author: Amin, Shaimaa Mohamed1    ; Ghallab, Eman2; Dreidi, Mutaz3; Alrimawi, Intima4; Mohamed, Shadia Ramadan Morsy21 Lecturer of Community Health Nursing, Faculty of Nursing, Damanhour University, Damanhour City, Egypt2 Nursing Education Department, Faculty of Nursing, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt3 Nursing Department, Faculty of Pharmacy, Nursing and Health Professions, Birzeit University, Birzeit, Palestine4 School of Nursing, Georgetown University, Washington, DC, USA

Publication info: Amin, Shaimaa Mohamed; Ghallab, Eman; Dreidi, Mutaz; Alrimawi, Intima; Mohamed, Shadia Ramadan Morsy. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/impact-diabetes-conversation-maptm-program-on/docview/3244144505/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background Diabetes mellitus is a growing global health concern, with a high prevalence in Egypt. Type 2 diabetes imposes substantial health and economic challenges. Diabetes Self‐Management Education and Support (DSMES) programs, such as the Diabetes Conversation Map, have demonstrated promise in enhancing patient knowledge, self‐management, and self‐efficacy. However, evidence regarding their direct impact remains scarce, necessitating further investigation. Objective This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Diabetes Conversation Map program in improving knowledge retention, self‐management, and self‐efficacy among type 2 diabetes patients in Egypt. Methods A prospective, parallel, two‐arm randomized controlled trial was conducted at the Damanhour Health Insurance Outpatient Diabetic Clinic in Egypt. A total of 120 adult patients with type 2 diabetes were randomized into a control group ( n  = 60), receiving standard diabetes education, and an intervention group ( n  = 60), attending 8 weekly interactive sessions using the Diabetes Conversation Map. Primary outcomes were assessed using validated questionnaires at baseline, post‐intervention, and 3 months later. Results The intervention group exhibited significant improvements in knowledge, self‐management, and self‐efficacy compared to the control group ( p  < 0.001). Additionally, positive correlations between these outcomes were observed post‐intervention, replacing negative correlations observed at baseline. Linking Evidence to Action The Diabetes Conversation Map program effectively enhances patient knowledge, self‐management, and self‐efficacy, supporting its integration into routine diabetes education. Healthcare providers should implement structured, interactive educational interventions to empower patients in managing their condition. Regular follow‐ups and reinforcement strategies are necessary to sustain long‐term self‐efficacy improvements. Policymakers should consider incorporating evidence‐based diabetes education into national healthcare programs. Future research should explore digital adaptations of the program to enhance accessibility and engagement. Trial Registration Registration No: R000061691, Trial ID: UMIN000054044

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Shaimaa&amp;aulast=Amin&amp;atitle=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self%E2%80%90Management%2C+and+Self%E2%80%90Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;stitle=Worldviews+on+Evidence-Based+Nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fwvn.70055&amp;title=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self%E2%80%90Management%2C+and+Self%E2%80%90Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;volume=22&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Shaimaa&amp;aulast=Amin&amp;atitle=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self%E2%80%90Management%2C+and+Self%E2%80%90Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;stitle=Worldviews+on+Evidence-Based+Nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fwvn.70055&amp;title=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self%E2%80%90Management%2C+and+Self%E2%80%90Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;volume=22&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Clinical trials; Patients; Diabetes; Intervention; Education

Title: Impact of the Diabetes Conversation MapTM Program on Knowledge Retention, Self‐Management, and Self‐Efficacy Among Diabetic Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Practical Insights and Perspectives: Enhancing CRNA Practice Through Longitudinal Assessment

Author: Gill, Christopher, PhD, MBA, CRNA, ACNPC-AG, FACHE; Berry, Kathryn, MEd, ICE-CCP; Choudhry, Shahid A, PhD, MPH; Ferris, Matt, MA, MBA, CAE, ELS; Muckle, Timothy J, PhD, ICE-CCP; Preston, John C, DNSc, CRNA, APRN, FAANA, FNAP, FAAN

Publication info: Gill, Christopher, PhD, MBA, CRNA, ACNPC-AG, FACHE; Berry, Kathryn, MEd, ICE-CCP; Choudhry, Shahid A, PhD, MPH; Ferris, Matt, MA, MBA, CAE, ELS; Muckle, Timothy J, PhD, ICE-CCP; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/practical-insights-perspectives-enhancing-crna/docview/3242411287/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This narrative review examines the implications of longitudinal assessment (LA) for certified registered nurse anesthetists, proposing it as an innovative method to enhance continuous professional development and maintain certification. Grounded in theoretical frameworks such as Miller's Pyramid of Clinical Competence and Moore's Expanded Outcomes Framework, this review explores how LA fosters lifelong learning in healthcare and synthesizes current evidence, detailing the integration of frequent, low-stakes assessments and targeted feedback to support knowledge retention and application. The principles of LA-flexibility, rigor, and relevance-are discussed with its potential to address the evolving demands of clinical practice, ensuring patient safety and competence. Key findings highlight the role of LA in reducing stress associated with traditional high-stakes testing while promoting engagement and critical thinking. This review highlights that LA represents a paradigm shift in healthcare education, aligning assessment methods with modern clinical and educational needs. By fostering continuous learning and adaptability, LA enhances clinician growth and improves patient outcomes. Further research is recommended to optimize LA implementation across diverse healthcare specialties.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Christopher&amp;aulast=Gill&amp;atitle=Practical+Insights+and+Perspectives%3A+Enhancing+CRNA+Practice+Through+Longitudinal+Assessment&amp;stitle=AANA+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.70278%2FAANAJ%2F.0000001038&amp;title=Practical+Insights+and+Perspectives%3A+Enhancing+CRNA+Practice+Through+Longitudinal+Assessment&amp;volume=93&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=259&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Christopher&amp;aulast=Gill&amp;atitle=Practical+Insights+and+Perspectives%3A+Enhancing+CRNA+Practice+Through+Longitudinal+Assessment&amp;stitle=AANA+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.70278%2FAANAJ%2F.0000001038&amp;title=Practical+Insights+and+Perspectives%3A+Enhancing+CRNA+Practice+Through+Longitudinal+Assessment&amp;volume=93&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=259&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Clinical competence; Principles; Patient safety; Lifelong learning; Careers; Clinical medicine; Feedback; Knowledge; Adult learning; Professional development; Certification

Business indexing term: Subject: Careers Professional development

Title: Practical Insights and Perspectives: Enhancing CRNA Practice Through Longitudinal Assessment

Impact of the Diabetes Conversation MapTM Program on Knowledge Retention, Self-Management, and Self-Efficacy Among Diabetic Patients: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Author: Amin, Shaimaa Mohamed1    ; Ghallab, Eman2; Dreidi, Mutaz3; Alrimawi, Intima4; Mohamed, Shadia Ramadan Morsy21 Lecturer of Community Health Nursing, Faculty of Nursing, Damanhour University, Damanhour City, Egypt2 Nursing Education Department, Faculty of Nursing, Alexandria University, Alexandria, Egypt3 Nursing Department, Faculty of Pharmacy, Nursing and Health Professions, Birzeit University, Birzeit, Palestine4 School of Nursing, Georgetown University, Washington, DC, USA

Publication info: Amin, Shaimaa Mohamed; Ghallab, Eman; Dreidi, Mutaz; Alrimawi, Intima; Mohamed, Shadia Ramadan Morsy. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/impact-diabetes-conversation-maptm-program-on/docview/3231647631/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a growing global health concern, with a high prevalence in Egypt. Type 2 diabetes imposes substantial health and economic challenges. Diabetes Self-Management Education and Support (DSMES) programs, such as the Diabetes Conversation Map, have demonstrated promise in enhancing patient knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy. However, evidence regarding their direct impact remains scarce, necessitating further investigation. BACKGROUND Diabetes mellitus is a growing global health concern, with a high prevalence in Egypt. Type 2 diabetes imposes substantial health and economic challenges. Diabetes Self-Management Education and Support (DSMES) programs, such as the Diabetes Conversation Map, have demonstrated promise in enhancing patient knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy. However, evidence regarding their direct impact remains scarce, necessitating further investigation.This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Diabetes Conversation Map program in improving knowledge retention, self-management, and self-efficacy among type 2 diabetes patients in Egypt. OBJECTIVE This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Diabetes Conversation Map program in improving knowledge retention, self-management, and self-efficacy among type 2 diabetes patients in Egypt.A prospective, parallel, two-arm randomized controlled trial was conducted at the Damanhour Health Insurance Outpatient Diabetic Clinic in Egypt. A total of 120 adult patients with type 2 diabetes were randomized into a control group (n = 60), receiving standard diabetes education, and an intervention group (n = 60), attending 8 weekly interactive sessions using the Diabetes Conversation Map. Primary outcomes were assessed using validated questionnaires at baseline, post-intervention, and 3 months later. METHODS A prospective, parallel, two-arm randomized controlled trial was conducted at the Damanhour Health Insurance Outpatient Diabetic Clinic in Egypt. A total of 120 adult patients with type 2 diabetes were randomized into a control group (n = 60), receiving standard diabetes education, and an intervention group (n = 60), attending 8 weekly interactive sessions using the Diabetes Conversation Map. Primary outcomes were assessed using validated questionnaires at baseline, post-intervention, and 3 months later.The intervention group exhibited significant improvements in knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Additionally, positive correlations between these outcomes were observed post-intervention, replacing negative correlations observed at baseline. RESULTS The intervention group exhibited significant improvements in knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy compared to the control group (p < 0.001). Additionally, positive correlations between these outcomes were observed post-intervention, replacing negative correlations observed at baseline.The Diabetes Conversation Map program effectively enhances patient knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy, supporting its integration into routine diabetes education. Healthcare providers should implement structured, interactive educational interventions to empower patients in managing their condition. Regular follow-ups and reinforcement strategies are necessary to sustain long-term self-efficacy improvements. Policymakers should consider incorporating evidence-based diabetes education into national healthcare programs. Future research should explore digital adaptations of the program to enhance accessibility and engagement. LINKING EVIDENCE TO ACTION The Diabetes Conversation Map program effectively enhances patient knowledge, self-management, and self-efficacy, supporting its integration into routine diabetes education. Healthcare providers should implement structured, interactive educational interventions to empower patients in managing their condition. Regular follow-ups and reinforcement strategies are necessary to sustain long-term self-efficacy improvements. Policymakers should consider incorporating evidence-based diabetes education into national healthcare programs. Future research should explore digital adaptations of the program to enhance accessibility and engagement.Registration No: R000061691, Trial ID: UMIN000054044. TRIAL REGISTRATION Registration No: R000061691, Trial ID: UMIN000054044.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Shaimaa&amp;aulast=Amin&amp;atitle=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self-Management%2C+and+Self-Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;stitle=Worldviews+on+evidence-based+nursing&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1111%2Fwvn.70055&amp;title=Impact+of+the+Diabetes+Conversation+MapTM+Program+on+Knowledge+Retention%2C+Self-Management%2C+and+Self-Efficacy+Among+Diabetic+Patients%3A+A+Randomized+Controlled+Trial&amp;volume=22&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=e70055&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Trauma‐Informed Practices as a Buffer Against Secondary Traumatic Stress: Insights From First‐Year Teachers

Author: Castro Schepers, Ofelia1    ; Grevstad, Nels2    ; Young, Kathryn2    ; Brennan, Megan31 Purdue University, West Lafayette, Indiana, USA2 Metropolitan State University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, USA3 Resilient Futures & Affiliate at Metropolitan State University of Denver, Denver, Colorado, USA

Publication info: Castro Schepers, Ofelia; Grevstad, Nels; Young, Kathryn; Brennan, Megan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/trauma-informed-practices-as-buffer-against/docview/3230744061/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study explores the impact of secondary traumatic stress (STS) on first‐year teachers (FYTs) and the potential of trauma‐informed practices (TIP) as a mitigating strategy. STS, which results from exposure to students' trauma, is a significant but underexplored issue in education. By examining the first year of teaching, this mixed‐methods study investigates whether TIP reduces STS symptoms and improves knowledge retention in FYTs. Quantitative findings suggest that TIP can enhance TIP content knowledge and confidence and reduce STS, offering valuable insights for teacher well‐being and retention, particularly in high‐needs schools. This study contributes to the emerging literature on STS in education and highlights the importance of targeted support for first‐year teachers.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ofelia&amp;aulast=Castro+Schepers&amp;atitle=Trauma%E2%80%90Informed+Practices+as+a+Buffer+Against+Secondary+Traumatic+Stress%3A+Insights+From+First%E2%80%90Year+Teachers&amp;stitle=Psychology+in+the+Schools&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fpits.23478&amp;title=Trauma%E2%80%90Informed+Practices+as+a+Buffer+Against+Secondary+Traumatic+Stress%3A+Insights+From+First%E2%80%90Year+Teachers&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=2463&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ofelia&amp;aulast=Castro+Schepers&amp;atitle=Trauma%E2%80%90Informed+Practices+as+a+Buffer+Against+Secondary+Traumatic+Stress%3A+Insights+From+First%E2%80%90Year+Teachers&amp;stitle=Psychology+in+the+Schools&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fpits.23478&amp;title=Trauma%E2%80%90Informed+Practices+as+a+Buffer+Against+Secondary+Traumatic+Stress%3A+Insights+From+First%E2%80%90Year+Teachers&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=2463&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Gamification-Based Teaching Methods for Pandemic and Outbreak Investigation Training Among Healthcare Professionals and Students: A Systematic Review

Author: Krishnamoorthy Yuvaraj1    ; Govindan Dhanajayan2; Karunakaran, Monica3; Parveen Muneera1; John, Poul Afrith1; Anaswara, Manohar1; Rajendran Gunaseelan41 682565 Partnership for Research, Opportunities, Planning, Upskilling and Leadership (PROPUL) Evidence , India2 421395 ESIC Medical College and Hospital , India3 638812 Sri Lalithambigai Medical College and Hospital , India4 Aarupadai Veedu Medical College and Hospital , India

Publication info: Krishnamoorthy Yuvaraj; Govindan Dhanajayan; Karunakaran, Monica; Parveen Muneera; John, Poul Afrith; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/gamification-based-teaching-methods-pandemic/docview/3224910001/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted urgent need for effective training in pandemic and outbreak management among healthcare professionals. Traditional teaching methods often lack the engagement required to prepare learners for real-world challenges. This systematic review evaluates effectiveness of gamification-based teaching methods in enhancing knowledge, skills, and engagement in pandemic preparedness education for healthcare professionals and students. Methods Systematic search was conducted across PubMed, Scopus, Cochrane, Google Scholar, and ScienceDirect databases, identifying studies that employed gamification-based learning for pandemic management training. Studies were screened and selected based on predefined eligibility criteria, focusing on interventions targeting healthcare professionals or students. 12 studies were included, and narrative synthesis was conducted due to the heterogeneity in study designs, participant groups, and outcome measures. Results Review found that gamification-based methods, such as serious games, e-learning modules, and simulations, improved knowledge retention, practical skills, and learner engagement compared to traditional teaching approaches. Participants reported high satisfaction and perceived usefulness of gamified interventions, with several studies demonstrating significant improvements in long-term knowledge retention and willingness to change behaviours related to infection control. However, variability in intervention design and outcome measures posed challenges for drawing generalized conclusions. Conclusion Gamification-based teaching methods show promise in enhancing pandemic preparedness training among healthcare professionals. While these methods improve engagement and learning outcomes, further research is needed to explore long-term impacts, cost-effectiveness, and applicability in diverse educational settings. In addition, heterogeneity and methodological limitations of included studies underscore the need for more rigorous, high-quality research to validate these findings.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Krishnamoorthy+Yuvaraj&amp;atitle=Gamification-Based+Teaching+Methods+for+Pandemic+and+Outbreak+Investigation+Training+Among+Healthcare+Professionals+and+Students%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;stitle=Simulation+%26+Gaming&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F10468781251338382&amp;title=Gamification-Based+Teaching+Methods+for+Pandemic+and+Outbreak+Investigation+Training+Among+Healthcare+Professionals+and+Students%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=392&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Krishnamoorthy+Yuvaraj&amp;atitle=Gamification-Based+Teaching+Methods+for+Pandemic+and+Outbreak+Investigation+Training+Among+Healthcare+Professionals+and+Students%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;stitle=Simulation+%26+Gaming&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1177%2F10468781251338382&amp;title=Gamification-Based+Teaching+Methods+for+Pandemic+and+Outbreak+Investigation+Training+Among+Healthcare+Professionals+and+Students%3A+A+Systematic+Review&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=392&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

ERIC Subject: Retention (Psychology); Management Development; Teaching Methods; Outcome Measures; Pandemics; Outcomes of Education; Professional Education; Learner Engagement; Learning Modules; Participant Satisfaction

From fighting fires to halting hemorrhage: the use of a self-training module to teach tourniquet placement to first responder firefighters in a resource-constrained area

Author: Levi, Amelia1; Monzón, José C2; Jhunjhunwala, Rashi3; Escalona, Gabriel4; Zinco, Analia5; Ottolino, Pablo5; Raykar, Nakul6; Asturias, Sabrina71 MedStar Georgetown/Washington Hospital Center, USA amelia.levi@medstar.net2 Rafael Landivar University Guatemala City, Guatemala City, Guatemala3 Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA, USA; Program in Global Surgery and Social Change, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA4 Faculty of Medicine, Experimental Surgery and Simulation Center, Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile, Santiago, Chile5 Hospital Sotero del Rio, Puente Alto, Chile6 Program in Global Surgery and Social Change, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA; Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA, USA7 Hospital Roosevelt, Ciudad de Guatemala, Guatemala

Publication info: Levi, Amelia; Monzón, José C; Jhunjhunwala, Rashi; Escalona, Gabriel; Zinco, Analia; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/fighting-fires-halting-hemorrhage-use-self/docview/3224254747/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Hemorrhage causes 40 % of deaths from trauma. Low- and middle- income countries (LMICs) claim the majority of these deaths, in part due to lack of resources and organization in the prehospital and hospital arenas. Guatemala experiences a high burden of trauma-related injuries but does not have the resources nor the emergency response system to deal with it. In Guatemala, firefighters (bomberos) lead trauma responses, yet do not receive medical training. Recognizing these gaps in LMICs, we developed "CrashSavers", a low cost, openly accessible, self-training mobile phone-based platform to teach hemorrhage control techniques to first responders in Guatemala City. In this manuscript, we present the evaluation and outcomes of the bomberos who were trained with CrashSavers. INTRODUCTION Hemorrhage causes 40 % of deaths from trauma. Low- and middle- income countries (LMICs) claim the majority of these deaths, in part due to lack of resources and organization in the prehospital and hospital arenas. Guatemala experiences a high burden of trauma-related injuries but does not have the resources nor the emergency response system to deal with it. In Guatemala, firefighters (bomberos) lead trauma responses, yet do not receive medical training. Recognizing these gaps in LMICs, we developed "CrashSavers", a low cost, openly accessible, self-training mobile phone-based platform to teach hemorrhage control techniques to first responders in Guatemala City. In this manuscript, we present the evaluation and outcomes of the bomberos who were trained with CrashSavers.Our self-administered educational program teaches first responders to train themselves in the decision making and psychomotor skills of tourniquet placement. This free platform, accessible via mobile phone, provides didactic material, virtual reality cases and instructions to construct a bleeding extremity simulator. Sixty-four bomberos were trained from July-August 2022. Eighteen months later they were retested to assess knowledge retention. Interviews were conducted with all bomberos to elicit feedback, which were then analyzed with narrative synthesis. We assessed medical knowledge, confidence, and surgical skills pre and post training. METHODS Our self-administered educational program teaches first responders to train themselves in the decision making and psychomotor skills of tourniquet placement. This free platform, accessible via mobile phone, provides didactic material, virtual reality cases and instructions to construct a bleeding extremity simulator. Sixty-four bomberos were trained from July-August 2022. Eighteen months later they were retested to assess knowledge retention. Interviews were conducted with all bomberos to elicit feedback, which were then analyzed with narrative synthesis. We assessed medical knowledge, confidence, and surgical skills pre and post training.After training, bomberos were able to apply the tourniquet more efficiently and more confidently. The time taken to stop a bleed on the simulator dropped from 58.5 s to 39.2 s, p < 0.003. Assessment of their skills 18 months after initial training showed that they were able to retain both confidence and psychomotor skill of tourniquet placement. Qualitative analysis showed overall positive experience with the course. RESULTS After training, bomberos were able to apply the tourniquet more efficiently and more confidently. The time taken to stop a bleed on the simulator dropped from 58.5 s to 39.2 s, p < 0.003. Assessment of their skills 18 months after initial training showed that they were able to retain both confidence and psychomotor skill of tourniquet placement. Qualitative analysis showed overall positive experience with the course.A low cost, easily accessible, self-taught course of didactics, VR cases and simulation successfully trained bomberos to control a bleeding extremity. This may be a solution for the large gaps in LMIC trauma response, as traditional programs designed for high income countries (HICs) are inaccessible, expensive and time intensive. With CrashSavers, learners became faster and more confident in stopping a bleed, and in a situation where time is blood and blood is life, efficiency is key. CONCLUSIONS A low cost, easily accessible, self-taught course of didactics, VR cases and simulation successfully trained bomberos to control a bleeding extremity. This may be a solution for the large gaps in LMIC trauma response, as traditional programs designed for high income countries (HICs) are inaccessible, expensive and time intensive. With CrashSavers, learners became faster and more confident in stopping a bleed, and in a situation where time is blood and blood is life, efficiency is key.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Amelia&amp;aulast=Levi&amp;atitle=From+fighting+fires+to+halting+hemorrhage%3A+the+use+of+a+self-training+module+to+teach+tourniquet+placement+to+first+responder+firefighters+in+a+resource-constrained+area&amp;stitle=Injury&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.injury.2025.112367&amp;title=From+fighting+fires+to+halting+hemorrhage%3A+the+use+of+a+self-training+module+to+teach+tourniquet+placement+to+first+responder+firefighters+in+a+resource-constrained+area&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=112367&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Amelia&amp;aulast=Levi&amp;atitle=From+fighting+fires+to+halting+hemorrhage%3A+the+use+of+a+self-training+module+to+teach+tourniquet+placement+to+first+responder+firefighters+in+a+resource-constrained+area&amp;stitle=Injury&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.injury.2025.112367&amp;title=From+fighting+fires+to+halting+hemorrhage%3A+the+use+of+a+self-training+module+to+teach+tourniquet+placement+to+first+responder+firefighters+in+a+resource-constrained+area&amp;volume=56&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=112367&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Supplemental data: Declaration of competing interest The Intuitive Foundation provided grant funding for the development and execution of this project via the Global Surgical Training Challenge., Indexing method: Automated

Title: From fighting fires to halting hemorrhage: the use of a self-training module to teach tourniquet placement to first responder firefighters in a resource-constrained area

Advancements in orthopaedic medical Education: Exploring novel teaching strategies - A qualitative systematic review

Author: Roy, Mainak1; Nandini, Dhanapal2; Murugan, Jayanth3; Khanna, Manish4; Patro, Bishnu Prasad5; Jayan, Abhijith K51 Department of Orthopaedics, All India Institute of Medical Sciences - Central Armed Police Forces Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS-CAPFIMS), New Delhi, India2 Department of Microbiology, Faculty of Medicine - Sri Lalithambigai Medical College and Hospital, Dr MGR Educational and Research Institute, Chennai, Tamil Nadu, India3 Department of Radio Diagnosis, SRM Medical College Hospital & Research Centre, SRM Institute of Science and Technology, Chengalpattu, Tamil Nadu, India4 Department of Orthopaedics, Dr KNS Mayo Institute of Medical Sciences, Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, India5 Department of Orthopaedics, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Bhubaneswar, Odisha, India

Publication info: Roy, Mainak; Nandini, Dhanapal; Murugan, Jayanth; Khanna, Manish; Patro, Bishnu Prasad; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/advancements-orthopaedic-medical-education/docview/3218156937/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The evolution of orthopaedic medical education has been significantly influenced by the integration of innovative teaching methods aimed at addressing the challenges of traditional learning models. Emerging pedagogical strategies such as simulation-based learning, flipped classrooms, problem-based learning (PBL), and peer teaching have demonstrated improved student engagement, knowledge retention, and clinical competency. However, the global adoption of these innovations faces barriers, particularly in resource-limited settings. Background The evolution of orthopaedic medical education has been significantly influenced by the integration of innovative teaching methods aimed at addressing the challenges of traditional learning models. Emerging pedagogical strategies such as simulation-based learning, flipped classrooms, problem-based learning (PBL), and peer teaching have demonstrated improved student engagement, knowledge retention, and clinical competency. However, the global adoption of these innovations faces barriers, particularly in resource-limited settings.This study explores the impact of novel teaching strategies in orthopaedic education through an extensive literature review and evaluation of current trends. The study methodology follows systematic analysis guidelines registered under PROSPERO (ID: CRD420251007591). Key parameters assessed include student engagement, knowledge retention, and clinical skill development. Methods This study explores the impact of novel teaching strategies in orthopaedic education through an extensive literature review and evaluation of current trends. The study methodology follows systematic analysis guidelines registered under PROSPERO (ID: CRD420251007591). Key parameters assessed include student engagement, knowledge retention, and clinical skill development.Findings indicate that simulation-based learning enhances surgical skill acquisition by offering repetitive practice opportunities in a controlled environment. The flipped classroom model improves conceptual understanding by allowing pre-class learning and interactive in-class application. PBL and peer teaching foster critical thinking, collaborative learning, and problem-solving skills. Despite financial and logistical challenges, institutions implementing these strategies report significant improvements in training outcomes. Results Findings indicate that simulation-based learning enhances surgical skill acquisition by offering repetitive practice opportunities in a controlled environment. The flipped classroom model improves conceptual understanding by allowing pre-class learning and interactive in-class application. PBL and peer teaching foster critical thinking, collaborative learning, and problem-solving skills. Despite financial and logistical challenges, institutions implementing these strategies report significant improvements in training outcomes.Innovative teaching strategies in orthopaedic education are crucial for enhancing training efficiency, student engagement, and clinical competency. However, global implementation requires overcoming technological, financial, and faculty training barriers. The findings emphasize the need for continued research and adaptation of these methods to ensure widespread accessibility and effectiveness in orthopaedic training programs. Conclusion Innovative teaching strategies in orthopaedic education are crucial for enhancing training efficiency, student engagement, and clinical competency. However, global implementation requires overcoming technological, financial, and faculty training barriers. The findings emphasize the need for continued research and adaptation of these methods to ensure widespread accessibility and effectiveness in orthopaedic training programs.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mainak&amp;aulast=Roy&amp;atitle=Advancements+in+orthopaedic+medical+Education%3A+Exploring+novel+teaching+strategies+-+A+qualitative+systematic+review&amp;stitle=Journal+of+clinical+orthopaedics+and+trauma&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1016%2Fj.jcot.2025.103059&amp;title=Advancements+in+orthopaedic+medical+Education%3A+Exploring+novel+teaching+strategies+-+A+qualitative+systematic+review&amp;volume=67&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=103059&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Trauma‐informed practices as a buffer against secondary traumatic stress: Insights from first‐year teachers

Author: Castro Schepers, Ofelia1    ; Grevstad, Nels2; Young, Kathryn2    ; Brennan, Megan31 Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, US oscheper@purdue.edu2 Metropolitan State University of Denver, Denver, CO, US3 Resilient Futures & Affiliate at Metropolitan State University of Denver, Denver, CO, US

Publication info: Castro Schepers, Ofelia; Grevstad, Nels; Young, Kathryn; Brennan, Megan. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/trauma-informed-practices-as-buffer-against/docview/3190335193/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This study explores the impact of secondary traumatic stress (STS) on first‐year teachers (FYTs) and the potential of trauma‐informed practices (TIP) as a mitigating strategy. STS, which results from exposure to students' trauma, is a significant but underexplored issue in education. By examining the first year of teaching, this mixed‐methods study investigates whether TIP reduces STS symptoms and improves knowledge retention in FYTs. Quantitative findings suggest that TIP can enhance TIP content knowledge and confidence and reduce STS, offering valuable insights for teacher well‐being and retention, particularly in high‐needs schools. This study contributes to the emerging literature on STS in education and highlights the importance of targeted support for first‐year teachers. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2026 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Ofelia&amp;aulast=Castro+Schepers&amp;atitle=Trauma%E2%80%90informed+practices+as+a+buffer+against+secondary+traumatic+stress%3A+Insights+from+first%E2%80%90year+teachers&amp;stitle=Psychology+in+the+Schools&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1002%2Fpits.23478&amp;title=Trauma%E2%80%90informed+practices+as+a+buffer+against+secondary+traumatic+stress%3A+Insights+from+first%E2%80%90year+teachers&amp;volume=62&amp;issue=8&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=2463&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;
