CBTIweb implementation outcomes: one-year follow up

Author: Wardle-Pinkston, Sophie1    ; Taylor, Daniel J1    ; Lin, Tao2    ; Dietch, Jessica R3    ; Pruiksma, Kristi4    ; Wilkerson, Allison K5    1 Department of Psychology, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, USA2 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, The Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, USA; Department of Psychiatry, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, USA3 School of Psychological Sciences, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, USA4 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, UT Health San Antonio, San Antonio, TX, USA5 Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, The Medical University of South Carolina, Charleston, SC, USA

Publication info: Wardle-Pinkston, Sophie; Taylor, Daniel J; Lin, Tao; Dietch, Jessica R; Pruiksma, Kristi; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/cbtiweb-implementation-outcomes-one-year-follow/docview/3155717404/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Insomnia is a common and debilitating disorder that is often undiagnosed and untreated. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI) is the first-line treatment for insomnia, though the lack of trained providers is a major barrier to accessibility. To address this issue, an online provider training platform, CBTI web , was launched in April 2020. The objective of this study was to determine the knowledge and implementation practices of providers 1 year after their successful completion of CBTI web . An online survey was sent to 569 providers who completed CBTI web training within 3 months of launch. Providers were asked about knowledge retention, use of CBTI with patients, barriers, and facilitators to the use of CBTI and acceptability, feasibility, and intervention appropriateness of CBTI. Two hundred and thirty-three providers completed the survey. Results revealed that most of the providers retained knowledge gained during CBTI web and that self-efficacy for CBTI was positively associated with CBTI use with their patients. Common barriers endorsed by providers were primarily related to difficulty promoting patient-buy-in for CBTI and difficulty finding CBTI supervision and consultation. Helpful facilitators included access to patient and therapist materials. Results also indicate very high acceptability (93.1%), agreeableness (94.3%), and feasibility (88.1%) of CBTI.Insomnia is a common and debilitating disorder that is often undiagnosed and untreated. Cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBTI) is the first-line treatment for insomnia, though the lack of trained providers is a major barrier to accessibility. To address this issue, an online provider training platform, CBTIweb, was launched in April 2020. The objective of this study was to determine the knowledge and implementation practices of providers 1 year after their successful completion of CBTIweb. An online survey was sent to 569 providers who completed CBTIweb training within 3 months of launch. Providers were asked about knowledge retention, use of CBTI with patients, barriers, and facilitators to the use of CBTI and acceptability, feasibility, and intervention appropriateness of CBTI. Two hundred and thirty-three providers completed the survey. Results revealed that most of the providers retained knowledge gained during CBTIweb and that self-efficacy for CBTI was positively associated with CBTI use with their patients. Common barriers endorsed by providers were primarily related to difficulty promoting patient-buy-in for CBTI and difficulty finding CBTI supervision and consultation. Helpful facilitators included access to patient and therapist materials. Results also indicate very high acceptability (93.1%), agreeableness (94.3%), and feasibility (88.1%) of CBTI.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Sophie&amp;aulast=Wardle-Pinkston&amp;atitle=CBTIweb+implementation+outcomes%3A+one-year+follow+up&amp;stitle=Cognitive+behaviour+therapy&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F16506073.2024.2442371&amp;title=CBTIweb+implementation+outcomes%3A+one-year+follow+up&amp;volume=54&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=557&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Sophie&amp;aulast=Wardle-Pinkston&amp;atitle=CBTIweb+implementation+outcomes%3A+one-year+follow+up&amp;stitle=Cognitive+behaviour+therapy&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1080%2F16506073.2024.2442371&amp;title=CBTIweb+implementation+outcomes%3A+one-year+follow+up&amp;volume=54&amp;issue=4&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=557&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Online Outcomes of a Pediatric Neuro-Oncology Course for Multidisciplinary Healthcare Professionals in Low- and Middle-Income Countries

Author: Berg, Fair1; Andujar, Allyson1; Chatman, Georgia1; Rodríguez-Galindo, Carlos1; Qaddoumi, Ibrahim1; Moreira, Daniel C1    1 Department of Global Pediatric Medicine, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 262 Danny Thomas Place, MS 721, Memphis, TN, USA daniel.moreira@stjude.org

Publication info: Berg, Fair; Andujar, Allyson; Chatman, Georgia; Rodríguez-Galindo, Carlos; Qaddoumi, Ibrahim; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/online-outcomes-pediatric-neuro-oncology-course/docview/3225871670/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Online and hybrid pediatric oncology training programs, such as the St. Jude Global Academy's Neuro-Oncology Training Seminar (NOTS), aim to address gaps in educational opportunities. This study examined the online components of the 2022 and 2023 NOTS, using mixed methods to assess strengths, limitations, and areas for improvement specific to the distance learning components. NOTS participants are required to complete 9 weeks of online modules. Participants were invited to evaluate their online learning experience which included both quantitative and qualitative measures related to participant perceptions of the course. Descriptive statistics were used to analyze quantitative results, and qualitative responses underwent thematic analysis. A total of 153 participants from 30 institutions participated in the online modules of the 2022 and 2023 NOTS. Among all participants, 106 (69.1%) completed the online course with a passing score of 70% or higher, and 83 completed the online evaluation. Pre-recorded lectures, rated highly by 73.5% of respondents, were appreciated for their content quality and flexibility. Live meetings were also of importance, with many participants requesting an expansion of interactive online sessions in future iterations of NOTS. Participants also felt the online learning activities (e.g., research projects and case discussions) were important and recommended more frequent knowledge assessments throughout the online modules and long-term follow-up. While most participants found the course duration of online components appropriate, some suggested adjustments to pacing and improved access to content. This study expands on the potential of technology-facilitated pediatric hematology-oncology education in LMICs by offering flexible and accessible learning formats. The findings suggest that blended learning models, interactive content, and incorporating peer and expert feedback can enhance knowledge retention and learner satisfaction among online participants.Online and hybrid pediatric oncology training programs, such as the St. Jude Global Academy's Neuro-Oncology Training Seminar (NOTS), aim to address gaps in educational opportunities. This study examined the online components of the 2022 and 2023 NOTS, using mixed methods to assess strengths, limitations, and areas for improvement specific to the distance learning components. NOTS participants are required to complete 9 weeks of online modules. Participants were invited to evaluate their online learning experience which included both quantitative and qualitative measures related to participant perceptions of the course. Descriptive statistics were used to analyze quantitative results, and qualitative responses underwent thematic analysis. A total of 153 participants from 30 institutions participated in the online modules of the 2022 and 2023 NOTS. Among all participants, 106 (69.1%) completed the online course with a passing score of 70% or higher, and 83 completed the online evaluation. Pre-recorded lectures, rated highly by 73.5% of respondents, were appreciated for their content quality and flexibility. Live meetings were also of importance, with many participants requesting an expansion of interactive online sessions in future iterations of NOTS. Participants also felt the online learning activities (e.g., research projects and case discussions) were important and recommended more frequent knowledge assessments throughout the online modules and long-term follow-up. While most participants found the course duration of online components appropriate, some suggested adjustments to pacing and improved access to content. This study expands on the potential of technology-facilitated pediatric hematology-oncology education in LMICs by offering flexible and accessible learning formats. The findings suggest that blended learning models, interactive content, and incorporating peer and expert feedback can enhance knowledge retention and learner satisfaction among online participants.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Fair&amp;aulast=Berg&amp;atitle=Online+Outcomes+of+a+Pediatric+Neuro-Oncology+Course+for+Multidisciplinary+Healthcare+Professionals+in+Low-+and+Middle-Income+Countries&amp;stitle=Journal+of+cancer+education+%3A+the+official+journal+of+the+American+Association+for+Cancer+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs13187-025-02681-4&amp;title=Online+Outcomes+of+a+Pediatric+Neuro-Oncology+Course+for+Multidisciplinary+Healthcare+Professionals+in+Low-+and+Middle-Income+Countries&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Fair&amp;aulast=Berg&amp;atitle=Online+Outcomes+of+a+Pediatric+Neuro-Oncology+Course+for+Multidisciplinary+Healthcare+Professionals+in+Low-+and+Middle-Income+Countries&amp;stitle=Journal+of+cancer+education+%3A+the+official+journal+of+the+American+Association+for+Cancer+Education&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs13187-025-02681-4&amp;title=Online+Outcomes+of+a+Pediatric+Neuro-Oncology+Course+for+Multidisciplinary+Healthcare+Professionals+in+Low-+and+Middle-Income+Countries&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Online Outcomes of a Pediatric Neuro-Oncology Course for Multidisciplinary Healthcare Professionals in Low- and Middle-Income Countries

Causality-Adjusted Data Augmentation for Domain Continual Medical Image Segmentation

Author: Zhu, Zhanshi; Dong, Qing; Luo, Gongning; Wang, Wei; Dong, Suyu; Wang, Kuanquan; Tian, Ye; Wang, Guohua; Li, Shuo

Publication info: Zhu, Zhanshi; Dong, Qing; Luo, Gongning; Wang, Wei; Dong, Suyu; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/causality-adjusted-data-augmentation-domain/docview/3224947290/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: In domain continual medical image segmentation, distillation-based methods mitigate catastrophic forgetting by continuously reviewing old knowledge. However, these approaches often exhibit biases towards both new and old knowledge simultaneously due to confounding factors, which can undermine segmentation performance. To address these biases, we propose the Causality-Adjusted Data Augmentation (CauAug) framework, introducing a novel causal intervention strategy called the Texture-Domain Adjustment Hybrid-Scheme (TDAHS) alongside two causality-targeted data augmentation approaches: the Cross Kernel Network (CKNet) and the Fourier Transformer Generator (FTGen). (1) TDAHS establishes a domain-continual causal model that accounts for two types of knowledge biases by identifying irrelevant local textures (L) and domain-specific features (D) as confounders. It introduces a hybrid causal intervention that combines traditional confounder elimination with a proposed replacement approach to better adapt to domain shifts, thereby promoting causal segmentation. (2) CKNet eliminates confounder L to reduce biases in new knowledge absorption. It decreases reliance on local textures in input images, forcing the model to focus on relevant anatomical structures and thus improving generalization. (3) FTGen causally intervenes on confounder D by selectively replacing it to alleviate biases that impact old knowledge retention. It restores domain-specific features in images, aiding in the comprehensive distillation of old knowledge. Our experiments show that CauAug significantly mitigates catastrophic forgetting and surpasses existing methods in various medical image segmentation tasks. The implementation code is publicly available at: https://github.com/PerceptionComputingLab/CauAug_DCMIS.In domain continual medical image segmentation, distillation-based methods mitigate catastrophic forgetting by continuously reviewing old knowledge. However, these approaches often exhibit biases towards both new and old knowledge simultaneously due to confounding factors, which can undermine segmentation performance. To address these biases, we propose the Causality-Adjusted Data Augmentation (CauAug) framework, introducing a novel causal intervention strategy called the Texture-Domain Adjustment Hybrid-Scheme (TDAHS) alongside two causality-targeted data augmentation approaches: the Cross Kernel Network (CKNet) and the Fourier Transformer Generator (FTGen). (1) TDAHS establishes a domain-continual causal model that accounts for two types of knowledge biases by identifying irrelevant local textures (L) and domain-specific features (D) as confounders. It introduces a hybrid causal intervention that combines traditional confounder elimination with a proposed replacement approach to better adapt to domain shifts, thereby promoting causal segmentation. (2) CKNet eliminates confounder L to reduce biases in new knowledge absorption. It decreases reliance on local textures in input images, forcing the model to focus on relevant anatomical structures and thus improving generalization. (3) FTGen causally intervenes on confounder D by selectively replacing it to alleviate biases that impact old knowledge retention. It restores domain-specific features in images, aiding in the comprehensive distillation of old knowledge. Our experiments show that CauAug significantly mitigates catastrophic forgetting and surpasses existing methods in various medical image segmentation tasks. The implementation code is publicly available at: https://github.com/PerceptionComputingLab/CauAug_DCMIS.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zhanshi&amp;aulast=Zhu&amp;atitle=Causality-Adjusted+Data+Augmentation+for+Domain+Continual+Medical+Image+Segmentation&amp;stitle=IEEE+journal+of+biomedical+and+health+informatics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FJBHI.2025.3584068&amp;title=Causality-Adjusted+Data+Augmentation+for+Domain+Continual+Medical+Image+Segmentation&amp;volume=PP&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zhanshi&amp;aulast=Zhu&amp;atitle=Causality-Adjusted+Data+Augmentation+for+Domain+Continual+Medical+Image+Segmentation&amp;stitle=IEEE+journal+of+biomedical+and+health+informatics&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1109%2FJBHI.2025.3584068&amp;title=Causality-Adjusted+Data+Augmentation+for+Domain+Continual+Medical+Image+Segmentation&amp;volume=PP&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Efficacy of mind maps and concept maps in enhancing academic performance among undergraduate medical students in the preclinical stage: a systematic review

Author: Aljamal, Husam1; Alawneh, Rama1; Derbas, Afnan1; Edaibes, Mohammad1; Ahmed, Aya1; Amer, Lama1; Alzoubi, Hiba1; Serhan, Hashem Abu21 Faculty of Medicine, Yarmouk University, Irbid, Jordan2 Department of Ophthalmology, Hamad Medical Corporation, Doha, Qatar Habuserhan@hamad.qa

Publication info: Aljamal, Husam; Alawneh, Rama; Derbas, Afnan; Edaibes, Mohammad; Ahmed, Aya; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/efficacy-mind-maps-concept-enhancing-academic/docview/3223641132/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: This systematic review aims to evaluate the impact of mind maps and Concept Maps on academic performance among undergraduate medical students in the preclinical stage. PURPOSE This systematic review aims to evaluate the impact of mind maps and Concept Maps on academic performance among undergraduate medical students in the preclinical stage.Our protocol was registered on PROSPERO (CRD42024529458). We followed PRISMA guidelines in conducting our systematic review. We searched PubMed, Scopus, Google Scholar, and Cochrane Library from inception to June 2024. We included only randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that involved undergraduate medical students in the preclinical stage, evaluated mind mapping and Concept Maps as the intervention, and compared it to traditional methods or no intervention, with academic performance as the primary outcome. A qualitative synthesis of the results was conducted, and where possible, effect sizes (e.g., Cohen's d) were calculated to quantify the impact of mind maps and concept maps on academic performance. The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool. The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool. METHODS Our protocol was registered on PROSPERO (CRD42024529458). We followed PRISMA guidelines in conducting our systematic review. We searched PubMed, Scopus, Google Scholar, and Cochrane Library from inception to June 2024. We included only randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that involved undergraduate medical students in the preclinical stage, evaluated mind mapping and Concept Maps as the intervention, and compared it to traditional methods or no intervention, with academic performance as the primary outcome. A qualitative synthesis of the results was conducted, and where possible, effect sizes (e.g., Cohen's d) were calculated to quantify the impact of mind maps and concept maps on academic performance. The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool. The risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias tool.A total of six RCTs were included. Four studies reported significantly higher assessment scores with the use of mind maps or concept maps. Teli et al. (Indian Journal of Clinical Anatomy and Physiology 7(2):243-246, 2020) observed a significant improvement in knowledge retention in the intervention group (mean score: 82.4% vs. 69.8%, p   0.05), but students consistently expressed a preference for these methods due to their utility in understanding and summarizing information. Overall, mind maps and concept maps prove to be effective tools for enhancing academic performance, especially in terms of knowledge retention and comprehension. RESULTS A total of six RCTs were included. Four studies reported significantly higher assessment scores with the use of mind maps or concept maps. Teli et al. (Indian Journal of Clinical Anatomy and Physiology 7(2):243-246, 2020) observed a significant improvement in knowledge retention in the intervention group (mean score: 82.4% vs. 69.8%, p   0.05), but students consistently expressed a preference for these methods due to their utility in understanding and summarizing information. Overall, mind maps and concept maps prove to be effective tools for enhancing academic performance, especially in terms of knowledge retention and comprehension.This systematic review shows that mind maps and Concept Maps are effective methods in helping undergraduate preclinical medical students achieve better performance, especially in terms of knowledge retention and comprehension. While not all studies showed significant differences, the overall preference for these methods indicates their potential as valuable learning tools. We recommend integrating these tools into preclinical curricula and providing training sessions to enhance their effectiveness. CONCLUSION This systematic review shows that mind maps and Concept Maps are effective methods in helping undergraduate preclinical medical students achieve better performance, especially in terms of knowledge retention and comprehension. While not all studies showed significant differences, the overall preference for these methods indicates their potential as valuable learning tools. We recommend integrating these tools into preclinical curricula and providing training sessions to enhance their effectiveness.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Husam&amp;aulast=Aljamal&amp;atitle=Efficacy+of+mind+maps+and+concept+maps+in+enhancing+academic+performance+among+undergraduate+medical+students+in+the+preclinical+stage%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;stitle=Advances+in+health+sciences+education+%3A+theory+and+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs10459-025-10437-4&amp;title=Efficacy+of+mind+maps+and+concept+maps+in+enhancing+academic+performance+among+undergraduate+medical+students+in+the+preclinical+stage%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Husam&amp;aulast=Aljamal&amp;atitle=Efficacy+of+mind+maps+and+concept+maps+in+enhancing+academic+performance+among+undergraduate+medical+students+in+the+preclinical+stage%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;stitle=Advances+in+health+sciences+education+%3A+theory+and+practice&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs10459-025-10437-4&amp;title=Efficacy+of+mind+maps+and+concept+maps+in+enhancing+academic+performance+among+undergraduate+medical+students+in+the+preclinical+stage%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Medical Students' Knowledge and Adherence to Paediatric Choking Rescue Manoeuvre Guidelines: A Multicentre Study of Medical Education Curricula

Author: Bieliński, Jakub R1    ; Huntley, Riley2    ; Timler, Dariusz1    ; Nadolny, Klaudiusz3    ; Jaskiewicz, Filip1    1 Emergency Medicine and Disaster Medicine Department, Medical University of Lodz, 90-419 Lodz, Poland2 Faculty of Applied Science, School of Nursing, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC V6T 2B5, Canada3 Department of Emergency Medical Service, Faculty of Medicine, Silesian Academy in Katowice, 40-555 Katowice, Poland; Collegium Medicum, WSB University, 41-300 Dabrowa Gornicza, Poland

Publication info: Bieliński, Jakub R; Huntley, Riley; Timler, Dariusz; Nadolny, Klaudiusz; Jaskiewicz, Filip. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/medical-students-knowledge-adherence-paediatric/docview/3224261236/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background/Objectives: Bystander first aid in paediatric choking is crucial. It ought to be universally comprehensible and backed up by evidence-based guidelines. However, there still are inconsistencies in guidelines worldwide. The objective of this research was to assess the knowledge of medical students on paediatric choking rescue manoeuvres and their educational backgrounds in order to evaluate the impact of differences in educational curricula. Methods: Medical students from a total of 12 universities across Canada, Libya, and Poland were surveyed online. The questionnaire assessed the respondents' experience, training, and knowledge in first aid regarding foreign body airway obstruction in infants and children. Results: Out of 324 responses, 290 were evaluated. Although the students studied in only 3 countries, they represented 37 countries of origin. A total of 7 new reference groups were created based on guideline identification. A comparison of 4 clinical scenario questions revealed that certain training providers communicate recommendations more effectively to medical students, as their guidelines seem to have better knowledge retention. Conclusions: There are important differences in medical student knowledge, possibly due to discrepancies in training programs and guidelines. Variability was found in body position, anti-choking suction devices, blind finger sweeps, and medical follow-ups. More research is needed to standardize training and improve worldwide choking management outcomes.Background/Objectives: Bystander first aid in paediatric choking is crucial. It ought to be universally comprehensible and backed up by evidence-based guidelines. However, there still are inconsistencies in guidelines worldwide. The objective of this research was to assess the knowledge of medical students on paediatric choking rescue manoeuvres and their educational backgrounds in order to evaluate the impact of differences in educational curricula. Methods: Medical students from a total of 12 universities across Canada, Libya, and Poland were surveyed online. The questionnaire assessed the respondents' experience, training, and knowledge in first aid regarding foreign body airway obstruction in infants and children. Results: Out of 324 responses, 290 were evaluated. Although the students studied in only 3 countries, they represented 37 countries of origin. A total of 7 new reference groups were created based on guideline identification. A comparison of 4 clinical scenario questions revealed that certain training providers communicate recommendations more effectively to medical students, as their guidelines seem to have better knowledge retention. Conclusions: There are important differences in medical student knowledge, possibly due to discrepancies in training programs and guidelines. Variability was found in body position, anti-choking suction devices, blind finger sweeps, and medical follow-ups. More research is needed to standardize training and improve worldwide choking management outcomes.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jakub&amp;aulast=Bieli%C5%84ski&amp;atitle=Medical+Students%27+Knowledge+and+Adherence+to+Paediatric+Choking+Rescue+Manoeuvre+Guidelines%3A+A+Multicentre+Study+of+Medical+Education+Curricula&amp;stitle=Healthcare+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fhealthcare13121441&amp;title=Medical+Students%27+Knowledge+and+Adherence+to+Paediatric+Choking+Rescue+Manoeuvre+Guidelines%3A+A+Multicentre+Study+of+Medical+Education+Curricula&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=12&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jakub&amp;aulast=Bieli%C5%84ski&amp;atitle=Medical+Students%27+Knowledge+and+Adherence+to+Paediatric+Choking+Rescue+Manoeuvre+Guidelines%3A+A+Multicentre+Study+of+Medical+Education+Curricula&amp;stitle=Healthcare+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fhealthcare13121441&amp;title=Medical+Students%27+Knowledge+and+Adherence+to+Paediatric+Choking+Rescue+Manoeuvre+Guidelines%3A+A+Multicentre+Study+of+Medical+Education+Curricula&amp;volume=13&amp;issue=12&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Evaluating the Effectiveness of the Flipped Classroom Model in Undergraduate Medical Education: A Quasi-experimental Study

Author: Patnaik Sibabratta1; Behera, Manas Ranjan1; Patnaik Lipilekha21 Pediatrics, Kalinga Institute of Medical Sciences, Bhubaneswar, IND2 Community Medicine, Institute of Medical Sciences & SUM Hospital, Bhubaneswar, IND

Publication info: Patnaik Sibabratta; Behera, Manas Ranjan; Patnaik Lipilekha. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/evaluating-effectiveness-flipped-classroom-model/docview/3234802162/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background: The flipped classroom (FC) model has gained increasing recognition as an innovative teaching strategy in medical education, addressing the limitations of passive learning in traditional methods. It takes learning outside the classroom and allows students to preview new material, while leaving classroom time for content-related discussions and joint tasks. However, limited studies have evaluated its impact in Eastern India, particularly in pediatric teaching. The study was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the FC model versus the traditional method of teaching in improving knowledge retention and engagement among undergraduate medical students studying pediatric respiratory illnesses. Materials and methods: A prospective quasi-experimental study was conducted over six months (November 2021 to April 2022) among 130 eighth-semester medical students at Kalinga Institute of Medical Sciences (KIMS), Bhubaneswar. Participants were divided into two groups: one receiving traditional lectures and the other exposed to FC sessions covering pediatric respiratory competencies. Pre- and post-test scores were compared using SPSS (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY) with a significance threshold of P < 0.05. The scores were compared, and their perception toward the teaching tool was assessed by a questionnaire-based survey. Results: A total of 130 students, 67 in the control group and 63 in the intervention group, were analyzed for their knowledge score at baseline by a pretested questionnaire. The mean score of knowledge among the control and intervention groups was not different at baseline (P = 0.519). Students in the FC group demonstrated a significantly greater improvement in knowledge scores (mean increase: 2.0 points) compared to the traditional group (mean increase: 0.925 points; P < 0.01). Additionally, 77.8% of participants reported increased engagement in the flipped sessions. Conclusions: The greater mean scores after the teaching sessions represent the improved perception of the FC teaching-learning approach for repeatability and better memory retention. The FC method was found to be more effective than the traditional method of teaching. The students’ feedback was positive toward the FC method. With careful preparation and faculty training, it can address the issue of medical students' lack of competency in pediatrics.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Patnaik+Sibabratta&amp;atitle=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+the+Flipped+Classroom+Model+in+Undergraduate+Medical+Education%3A+A+Quasi-experimental+Study&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.86312&amp;title=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+the+Flipped+Classroom+Model+in+Undergraduate+Medical+Education%3A+A+Quasi-experimental+Study&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Patnaik+Sibabratta&amp;atitle=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+the+Flipped+Classroom+Model+in+Undergraduate+Medical+Education%3A+A+Quasi-experimental+Study&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.86312&amp;title=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+the+Flipped+Classroom+Model+in+Undergraduate+Medical+Education%3A+A+Quasi-experimental+Study&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Preparing Medical Students for Sideline Sports Care in Underserved Communities: A Comparison of Simulation and Lecture-Based Training

Author: Elnaggar Alqasim1; Abdelnour, David1; Chauhdri Ammar1; Miller, Candice1; Rafique Rumyah1; Mao, Jack1; Frei, Ashley1; Naessig Sara1; Johnson, Julian D1; Sternberg Marley1; Millar, Audrey1; Court Tannor2; Fong, Nham2; Daher, Ahmed3; Gupta, Andrew2; Gatz, Joshua3; Dimovski Radomir2; Alexander, James4; Geamanu Andreea1; Vaidya Rahul21 Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, USA2 Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Wayne State University Detroit Medical Center, Detroit, USA3 Department of Family Medicine, Wayne State University School of Medicine, Detroit, USA4 Athletics, Detroit Public Schools Community District, Detroit, USA

Publication info: Elnaggar Alqasim; Abdelnour, David; Chauhdri Ammar; Miller, Candice; Rafique Rumyah; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/preparing-medical-students-sideline-sports-care/docview/3234800056/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Introduction: Access to sideline medical care is limited in many public-school athletic programs, especially in underserved urban areas. The Detroit Public School Health Corps (DPSHC) was founded in response to the tragic death of a Detroit public school basketball player who suffered a cardiac arrest during a game, underscoring the critical need for timely and effective sideline emergency care. DPSHC is a student-led inreach initiative targeting local healthcare gaps by providing equity-driven medical training in nearby schools. This study tests the hypothesis that simulation-based training will be more effective than traditional didactic training in improving a student volunteer’s clinical preparedness, knowledge retention, and confidence in sideline medical roles. The primary objectives are to compare confidence and knowledge gains between the two training methods, while a secondary objective evaluates the perceived impact of resident physician involvement during simulation. Methods: Forty-seven medical student volunteers completed either lecture-based (n=16) or simulation-based (n=31) training. Both groups completed identical pre- and post-training surveys assessing confidence in managing sports injuries and clinical knowledge. Paired t-tests analyzed the data to evaluate within-group improvements from before to after a training session, while independent t-tests compared the degree of improvement between training formats. Results: Both groups showed a significant improvement in confidence (p < 0.001). The simulation group showed greater confidence gains than the lecture group (33.06% vs. 24.53%, p = 0.02). Knowledge scores improved more in the simulation group (62.1% vs. 31.25%), though not significantly (p = 0.153). Resident physician involvement was rated invaluable by 25 (80.6%) of the simulation participants. Conclusion: Simulation-based training enhanced medical student volunteers’ confidence more than lecture-based methods in sideline care roles within an inreach program addressing healthcare disparities. These findings support the expansion of simulation-based learning as a core component of equity-driven, community-embedded medical education.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Elnaggar+Alqasim&amp;atitle=Preparing+Medical+Students+for+Sideline+Sports+Care+in+Underserved+Communities%3A+A+Comparison+of+Simulation+and+Lecture-Based+Training&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.86208&amp;title=Preparing+Medical+Students+for+Sideline+Sports+Care+in+Underserved+Communities%3A+A+Comparison+of+Simulation+and+Lecture-Based+Training&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Elnaggar+Alqasim&amp;atitle=Preparing+Medical+Students+for+Sideline+Sports+Care+in+Underserved+Communities%3A+A+Comparison+of+Simulation+and+Lecture-Based+Training&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.86208&amp;title=Preparing+Medical+Students+for+Sideline+Sports+Care+in+Underserved+Communities%3A+A+Comparison+of+Simulation+and+Lecture-Based+Training&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Subject: Ankle; Health care access; Simulation; Medical education; Experiential learning; Self report; Knowledge; Knee; Diagnostic tests; Concussion; Clinical decision making; Community; Confidence; Didacticism; Medical students; Orthopedics; Volunteers; High school basketball; Ligaments; Sports injuries; Skills

Enhancing Student Engagement Through Active Teaching-Learning Approaches Among First-Year Medical Undergraduates

Author: Rangareddy Harish1; Govinda Swamy K S2; Ashakiran, S1; Petimani Mahalaxmi S11 Biochemistry, Haveri Institute of Medical Sciences, Haveri, IND2 Biochemistry, Shimoga Institute of Medical Sciences, Shimoga, IND

Publication info: Rangareddy Harish; Govinda Swamy K S; Ashakiran, S; Petimani Mahalaxmi S. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/enhancing-student-engagement-through-active/docview/3225685560/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background Active teaching-learning approaches involve students in the learning process, promoting critical thinking, problem-solving, and knowledge retention. These methods contrast with traditional didactic lectures, which focus on passive listening. This study aims to evaluate the perceptions and effectiveness of active teaching-learning methods among first-year medical students. Methodology A cross-sectional survey of 113 first-year medical students was conducted using a validated questionnaire (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.873). Active teaching-learning methods, viz., small group discussions, case-based learning, flipped classroom, and early clinical exposure sessions, were implemented to enhance engagement among first-year MBBS students. The survey collected data on engagement, retention, and critical thinking through Likert-scale questions and open-ended feedback. Data were analyzed using SPSS version 16 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). Results Overall, 79.7% of students agreed that active teaching methods enhanced engagement, while 75.2% reported improved retention. Further, 83.2% felt their clinical reasoning skills benefited. Students emphasized the importance of interactive sessions and real-life clinical case discussions. Conclusions Active teaching-learning approaches improve engagement and critical thinking, aligning with the needs of modern medical education. Integration of these methods into the curriculum, alongside adequate resource allocation, is crucial for long-term success.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Rangareddy+Harish&amp;atitle=Enhancing+Student+Engagement+Through+Active+Teaching-Learning+Approaches+Among+First-Year+Medical+Undergraduates&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.85921&amp;title=Enhancing+Student+Engagement+Through+Active+Teaching-Learning+Approaches+Among+First-Year+Medical+Undergraduates&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=Rangareddy+Harish&amp;atitle=Enhancing+Student+Engagement+Through+Active+Teaching-Learning+Approaches+Among+First-Year+Medical+Undergraduates&amp;stitle=Cureus&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.7759%2Fcureus.85921&amp;title=Enhancing+Student+Engagement+Through+Active+Teaching-Learning+Approaches+Among+First-Year+Medical+Undergraduates&amp;volume=17&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Artificial Intelligence Outperforms Physicians in General Medical Knowledge, Except in the Paediatrics Domain: A Cross-Sectional Study

Author: Miranda, Joana1    ; Pereira-Silva, Raquel1; Guichard, João1; Meneses, Jorge1; Carreira, Andreia Neves1; Seixas, Daniela11 Tonic Easy Medical, S.A., 4300-259 Porto, Portugal

Publication info: Miranda, Joana; Pereira-Silva, Raquel; Guichard, João; Meneses, Jorge; Carreira, Andreia Neves; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/artificial-intelligence-outperforms-physicians/docview/3224258832/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Generative artificial intelligence (genAI) shows promising results in clinical practice. This study compared a GPT-4-turbo virtual assistant with physicians from Italy, France, Spain, and Portugal on medical knowledge derived from national exams while analysing knowledge retention over time and domain-specific performance. Via a digital platform, 17,144 physicians provided 221,574 answers to 600 exam questions between December 2022 and February 2024. Physicians were stratified by years since graduation and specialty, and the assistant answered the same questions in each native language. Differences in proportions of correct answers were tested with binomial logistic regression (odds ratios, 95% CI) or Fisher's exact test (α = 0.05). The assistant outperformed physicians in all countries (72-96% vs. 46-62%; logistic regression, p < 0.001). Physicians also trailed the assistant across most knowledge domains ( p < 0.001), except paediatrics (45% vs. 52%; Fisher, p = 0.60). Accuracy declined with seniority, falling 4-10% between the youngest and oldest cohorts (logistic regression, p < 0.001). Overall, genAI exceeds practising doctors on broad medical knowledge and may help counter knowledge attrition, though paediatrics remains a domain requiring targeted refinement.Generative artificial intelligence (genAI) shows promising results in clinical practice. This study compared a GPT-4-turbo virtual assistant with physicians from Italy, France, Spain, and Portugal on medical knowledge derived from national exams while analysing knowledge retention over time and domain-specific performance. Via a digital platform, 17,144 physicians provided 221,574 answers to 600 exam questions between December 2022 and February 2024. Physicians were stratified by years since graduation and specialty, and the assistant answered the same questions in each native language. Differences in proportions of correct answers were tested with binomial logistic regression (odds ratios, 95% CI) or Fisher's exact test (α = 0.05). The assistant outperformed physicians in all countries (72-96% vs. 46-62%; logistic regression, p < 0.001). Physicians also trailed the assistant across most knowledge domains (p < 0.001), except paediatrics (45% vs. 52%; Fisher, p = 0.60). Accuracy declined with seniority, falling 4-10% between the youngest and oldest cohorts (logistic regression, p < 0.001). Overall, genAI exceeds practising doctors on broad medical knowledge and may help counter knowledge attrition, though paediatrics remains a domain requiring targeted refinement.

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Joana&amp;aulast=Miranda&amp;atitle=Artificial+Intelligence+Outperforms+Physicians+in+General+Medical+Knowledge%2C+Except+in+the+Paediatrics+Domain%3A+A+Cross-Sectional+Study&amp;stitle=Bioengineering+%28Basel%2C+Switzerland%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fbioengineering12060653&amp;title=Artificial+Intelligence+Outperforms+Physicians+in+General+Medical+Knowledge%2C+Except+in+the+Paediatrics+Domain%3A+A+Cross-Sectional+Study&amp;volume=12&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Impact of iSupport on improving knowledge on dementia and dementia care among family caregivers to persons with dementia and formal caregivers in Bangladesh: Protocol for a non-randomized feasibility study

Author: Islam, Muhammed Nazmul1    ; Musarrat, Parsa1    ; Konradsen, Hanne2    ; Tyrrell, Marie3; Roy, Antara1; Anik, Asibul Islam1    ; Kabir, Zarina Nahar3    1 Research and Evaluation Department, SAJIDA Foundation, Dhaka, Bangladesh nazmulislam@sajida.org2 North Zealand Hospital, Hillerod, Denmark3 Department of Neurobiology, Care Sciences and Society, Karolinska Institutet, Huddinge, Sweden

Publication info: Islam, Muhammed Nazmul; Musarrat, Parsa; Konradsen, Hanne; Tyrrell, Marie; Roy, Antara; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/impact-isupport-on-improving-knowledge-dementia/docview/3266069612/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Dementia is a growing global public health concern, particularly in LMICs like Bangladesh. With population aging, there is an increasing prevalence of dementia; care facilities are limited. This scarcity of services places a significant responsibility on untrained family caregivers, impacting the health of persons with dementia and their caregivers. Addressing these challenges is crucial for improving dementia care, especially in resource-constrained settings. Recognizing the urgency, the WHO developed an online self-training manual, iSupport, emphasizing education, skill development, and support for caregivers. This study aims to test feasibility of iSupport i) in improving knowledge about dementia and dementia care among family and formal caregivers, and ii) reducing family caregivers’ stress and improving their caregiving skills, mental health, quality of life and relationship with the person with dementia cared for. The study protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of SAJIDA Foundation (2024–005-SFIRB). This non-randomized feasibility study aims to recruit 44 family caregivers and 132 formal caregivers from Dhaka, Bangladesh, using a purposive sampling technique. Participants will be provided access to iSupport for two months. Pre- and post-intervention surveys will be conducted to assess changes in knowledge about dementia care among both family and formal caregivers, as well as changes in psychological well-being among family caregivers. To assess knowledge retention, a follow-up survey will be conducted. Any differences in the outcomes from the pre-intervention period will be tested against the null hypothesis of zero mean difference using a two-sample paired t-test. Additionally, multivariable regression techniques will also be used to control for possible confounders. To understand the facilitators and barriers of implementing iSupport, a qualitative approach will be used to interview 15 family caregivers and conduct four FGDs with formal caregivers. Qualitative data will be analysed using an inductive content analysis approach. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2025 APA, all rights reserved) (Source: journal abstract)

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Muhammed&amp;aulast=Islam&amp;atitle=Impact+of+iSupport+on+improving+knowledge+on+dementia+and+dementia+care+among+family+caregivers+to+persons+with+dementia+and+formal+caregivers+in+Bangladesh%3A+Protocol+for+a+non-randomized+feasibility+study&amp;stitle=PLoS+ONE&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0326207&amp;title=Impact+of+iSupport+on+improving+knowledge+on+dementia+and+dementia+care+among+family+caregivers+to+persons+with+dementia+and+formal+caregivers+in+Bangladesh%3A+Protocol+for+a+non-randomized+feasibility+study&amp;volume=20&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=e0326207&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Muhammed&amp;aulast=Islam&amp;atitle=Impact+of+iSupport+on+improving+knowledge+on+dementia+and+dementia+care+among+family+caregivers+to+persons+with+dementia+and+formal+caregivers+in+Bangladesh%3A+Protocol+for+a+non-randomized+feasibility+study&amp;stitle=PLoS+ONE&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0326207&amp;title=Impact+of+iSupport+on+improving+knowledge+on+dementia+and+dementia+care+among+family+caregivers+to+persons+with+dementia+and+formal+caregivers+in+Bangladesh%3A+Protocol+for+a+non-randomized+feasibility+study&amp;volume=20&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=e0326207&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Evaluating the Effectiveness of Educational Intervention on ICU Nurses' Knowledge of Delirium: A Quasi-Experimental Approach

Author: Qaddumi, Jamal1    ; Awawdi, Khaled2    ; Tarabeih, Mahdi1    1 Department of Nephrology, An-Najah National University Hospital, Omar Ibn Al-Khattab St., Nablus P.O. Box 7, Palestine; Department of Public Health, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, An-Najah National University, Nablus P.O. Box 7, Palestine2 Department of Public Health, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, An-Najah National University, Nablus P.O. Box 7, Palestine

Publication info: Qaddumi, Jamal; Awawdi, Khaled; Tarabeih, Mahdi. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/evaluating-effectiveness-educational-intervention/docview/3223935203/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Background and Objective: Delirium, a prevalent neurocognitive disorder, frequently affects critically ill patients hospitalized in intensive care units (ICUs), leading to increased mortality, prolonged hospital stays, and higher healthcare costs. This quasi-experimental study assessed the effect of an educational program relating to ICU nurses' knowledge of delirium in a university hospital in Nablus, Palestinian Authority. Methods: A pre-test-post-test design was employed, utilizing a 25-item questionnaire for 114 ICU nurses. The educational intervention included a presentation on delirium, the distribution of educational materials, and follow-up video sessions. Our study aim was to evaluate nurses' understanding of ICU delirium and the impact of the educational program on their ability to identify and evaluate the delirium. Results : Pre-intervention assessments indicated limited awareness among nurses regarding delirium diagnosis and management tools, i.e., the Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU (CAM-ICU) and the Intensive Care Delirium Screening Checklist. Post-intervention results showed a significant improvement in knowledge; median scores increased from 6 (range: 3-13) to 15 (range: 12-20) ( p < 0.001). Nurses also reported greater confidence in identifying and managing delirium, and 50% found CAM-ICU easy to use. However, knowledge gaps remained concerning mixed delirium types and modifiable risk factors. Conclusions: Continuous educational programs are essential for ensuring long-term knowledge retention. We recommend integrating routine delirium education with hospital policies and emphasizing the use of delirium assessment tools during each shift. Findings show that targeted education can enhance ICU nurses' competencies and thereby improve patient outcomes through more effective delirium management.Background and Objective: Delirium, a prevalent neurocognitive disorder, frequently affects critically ill patients hospitalized in intensive care units (ICUs), leading to increased mortality, prolonged hospital stays, and higher healthcare costs. This quasi-experimental study assessed the effect of an educational program relating to ICU nurses' knowledge of delirium in a university hospital in Nablus, Palestinian Authority. Methods: A pre-test-post-test design was employed, utilizing a 25-item questionnaire for 114 ICU nurses. The educational intervention included a presentation on delirium, the distribution of educational materials, and follow-up video sessions. Our study aim was to evaluate nurses' understanding of ICU delirium and the impact of the educational program on their ability to identify and evaluate the delirium. Results: Pre-intervention assessments indicated limited awareness among nurses regarding delirium diagnosis and management tools, i.e., the Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU (CAM-ICU) and the Intensive Care Delirium Screening Checklist. Post-intervention results showed a significant improvement in knowledge; median scores increased from 6 (range: 3-13) to 15 (range: 12-20) (p < 0.001). Nurses also reported greater confidence in identifying and managing delirium, and 50% found CAM-ICU easy to use. However, knowledge gaps remained concerning mixed delirium types and modifiable risk factors. Conclusions: Continuous educational programs are essential for ensuring long-term knowledge retention. We recommend integrating routine delirium education with hospital policies and emphasizing the use of delirium assessment tools during each shift. Findings show that targeted education can enhance ICU nurses' competencies and thereby improve patient outcomes through more effective delirium management.

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Jamal&amp;aulast=Qaddumi&amp;atitle=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+Educational+Intervention+on+ICU+Nurses%27+Knowledge+of+Delirium%3A+A+Quasi-Experimental+Approach&amp;stitle=Nursing+reports+%28Pavia%2C+Italy%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.3390%2Fnursrep15060205&amp;title=Evaluating+the+Effectiveness+of+Educational+Intervention+on+ICU+Nurses%27+Knowledge+of+Delirium%3A+A+Quasi-Experimental+Approach&amp;volume=15&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Educational Intervention on ICU Nurses' Knowledge of Delirium: A Quasi-Experimental Approach

Enhancing pedagogical practice through immersive technology with the transformation of classrooms with AR

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/conference-papers-proceedings/enhancing-pedagogical-practice-through-immersive/docview/3216195968/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The use of immersive technology, especially Augmented Reality (AR), is transforming teaching methods by establishing dynamic and interactive learning spaces. This study investigates how augmented reality (AR) improves instruction by fusing virtual and actual classroom environments, providing students with a more personalised and engaging learning environment. Teachers can convert standard instruction into immersive, multi-sensory lessons that promote greater learning and recall of difficult subjects by incorporating augmented reality (AR) into their curricula. The study looks at different AR applications in education and shows how they affect knowledge retention, collaborative learning, and student engagement. There is also discussion of difficulties like affordability, accessibility, and the requirement for teacher training. According to the research, augmented reality (AR) has the power to completely transform classrooms by increasing student engagement, personalisation, and adaptability to their unique needs. This will eventually boost pedagogical efficacy and spur innovation in the field of education.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=&amp;atitle=Enhancing+pedagogical+practice+through+immersive+technology+with+the+transformation+of+classrooms+with+AR&amp;stitle=AIP+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1063%2F5.0275886&amp;title=Enhancing+pedagogical+practice+through+immersive+technology+with+the+transformation+of+classrooms+with+AR&amp;volume=3306&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=&amp;aulast=&amp;atitle=Enhancing+pedagogical+practice+through+immersive+technology+with+the+transformation+of+classrooms+with+AR&amp;stitle=AIP+Conference+Proceedings&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1063%2F5.0275886&amp;title=Enhancing+pedagogical+practice+through+immersive+technology+with+the+transformation+of+classrooms+with+AR&amp;volume=3306&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=proceeding&amp;

Subject: Teaching methods; Augmented reality; Learning; Classrooms; Education; Teachers

Title: Enhancing pedagogical practice through immersive technology with the transformation of classrooms with AR

The potentials and challenges of integrating generative artificial intelligence (AI) in dental and orthodontic education: a systematic review

Author: Baxmann, Martin1; Kárpáti, Krisztina2; Baráth, Zoltán31 Department of Orthodontics, Faculty of Education and Research, DTMD University, Wiltz, 9516, Luxembourg info@orthodentix.de2 Department of Orthodontics and Pediatric Dentistry, Faculty of Dentistry, University of Szeged, Szeged, 6720, Hungary3 Department of Prosthodontics, Faculty of Dentistry, University of Szeged, Szeged, 6720, Hungary

Publication info: Baxmann, Martin; Kárpáti, Krisztina; Baráth, Zoltán. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/potentials-challenges-integrating-generative/docview/3215570877/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Generative AI technologies offer significant opportunities to enhance orthodontic education by improving knowledge retention, clinical decision-making, and skills training. This systematic review aimed to evaluate the impact of generative AI tools in orthodontic education, focusing on knowledge retention, decision-making, and practical skills. BACKGROUND Generative AI technologies offer significant opportunities to enhance orthodontic education by improving knowledge retention, clinical decision-making, and skills training. This systematic review aimed to evaluate the impact of generative AI tools in orthodontic education, focusing on knowledge retention, decision-making, and practical skills.A comprehensive literature search was conducted across PubMed, Cochrane Library, ERIC, CINAHL, and IEEE Xplore from January 2010 to December 2023. Studies evaluating the integration of generative AI in dental and orthodontic education were included. Seventeen studies met the inclusion criteria. Risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool and the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale, with the GRADE approach used to evaluate evidence quality. METHODS A comprehensive literature search was conducted across PubMed, Cochrane Library, ERIC, CINAHL, and IEEE Xplore from January 2010 to December 2023. Studies evaluating the integration of generative AI in dental and orthodontic education were included. Seventeen studies met the inclusion criteria. Risk of bias was assessed using the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool and the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale, with the GRADE approach used to evaluate evidence quality.Generative AI improved knowledge retention and clinical decision-making through adaptive learning pathways and real-time feedback. Barriers included limited faculty training, technical infrastructure deficits, and educator resistance. RESULTS Generative AI improved knowledge retention and clinical decision-making through adaptive learning pathways and real-time feedback. Barriers included limited faculty training, technical infrastructure deficits, and educator resistance.Generative AI holds transformative potential for orthodontic education but requires addressing practical and ethical challenges. Future research should focus on longitudinal studies to validate long-term impact and explore integration strategies. CONCLUSIONS Generative AI holds transformative potential for orthodontic education but requires addressing practical and ethical challenges. Future research should focus on longitudinal studies to validate long-term impact and explore integration strategies.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Martin&amp;aulast=Baxmann&amp;atitle=The+potentials+and+challenges+of+integrating+generative+artificial+intelligence+%28AI%29+in+dental+and+orthodontic+education%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;stitle=BMC+oral+health&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs12903-025-06070-7&amp;title=The+potentials+and+challenges+of+integrating+generative+artificial+intelligence+%28AI%29+in+dental+and+orthodontic+education%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;volume=25&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=905&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Martin&amp;aulast=Baxmann&amp;atitle=The+potentials+and+challenges+of+integrating+generative+artificial+intelligence+%28AI%29+in+dental+and+orthodontic+education%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;stitle=BMC+oral+health&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1186%2Fs12903-025-06070-7&amp;title=The+potentials+and+challenges+of+integrating+generative+artificial+intelligence+%28AI%29+in+dental+and+orthodontic+education%3A+a+systematic+review&amp;volume=25&amp;issue=1&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=905&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

Assessing Anaphylaxis: Improving Residents' Identification of a Life-Threatening Condition via a Focused Didactic and Case-Based Discussion

Author: Mistry, Hetal D1; Sharkey, Katherine M2; Andrea, Sarah B3; Settipane, Russell4; Kimberly, Judy5; Banerjee, Debasree61 Resident, Division of General Internal Medicine, Department of Medicine, Brown University2 Associate Professor, Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care, and Sleep Medicine, Department of Medicine; Assistant Professor, Department of Psychiatry & Human Behavior, Brown University3 Assistant Professor, Epidemiology, Oregon Health and Science University-Portland State University School of Public Health4 Professor, Division of Allergy and Immunology, Department of Medicine, Brown University5 Evaluation Director, Division of Biology and Medicine, Brown University6 Associate Professor, Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care, and Sleep Medicine, Department of Medicine, Brown University

Publication info: Mistry, Hetal D; Sharkey, Katherine M; Andrea, Sarah B; Settipane, Russell; Kimberly, Judy; et al. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/assessing-anaphylaxis-improving-residents/docview/3213606101/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening condition encountered by all physicians and healthcare providers. Data indicate that physicians often fail to recognize this syndrome, leading to misdiagnosis, mismanagement, and adverse outcomes. This educational program aimed to assess knowledge about anaphylaxis in a cohort of internal medicine residents and develop and test the efficacy of an educational intervention in addressing gaps in understanding of this critical condition. INTRODUCTION Anaphylaxis is a life-threatening condition encountered by all physicians and healthcare providers. Data indicate that physicians often fail to recognize this syndrome, leading to misdiagnosis, mismanagement, and adverse outcomes. This educational program aimed to assess knowledge about anaphylaxis in a cohort of internal medicine residents and develop and test the efficacy of an educational intervention in addressing gaps in understanding of this critical condition.An in-person educational intervention, including a lecture and case-based open discussion, was delivered to 44 internal medicine residents at an academic medical center with pre- and post-intervention self- assessments. Our primary outcome was the change in the rate of residents being able to correctly identify critical features of anaphylaxis and appropriate treatment. Longer-term follow-up was completed in a subset of residents to assess knowledge retention. METHODS An in-person educational intervention, including a lecture and case-based open discussion, was delivered to 44 internal medicine residents at an academic medical center with pre- and post-intervention self- assessments. Our primary outcome was the change in the rate of residents being able to correctly identify critical features of anaphylaxis and appropriate treatment. Longer-term follow-up was completed in a subset of residents to assess knowledge retention.Immediately following the educational intervention, there was increased likelihood of diagnosing anaphylaxis in a written case scenario from 69% to 91% (RR: 1.30; 95% CI 1.09,1.56) and reporting the correct dose and route of administration of epinephrine from 19% to 95% (RR:4.96; 95% CI: 2.26, 10.88). Residents also demonstrated increased identification of cardiovascular compromise in anaphylaxis, as well as often underrecognized gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms after the intervention. In an assessment evaluating longitudinal retention up to 15 months after the intervention, approximately 50% of those who responded to the longitudinal survey correctly recalled the dosing and route of administration of epinephrine for treating anaphylaxis. RESULTS Immediately following the educational intervention, there was increased likelihood of diagnosing anaphylaxis in a written case scenario from 69% to 91% (RR: 1.30; 95% CI 1.09,1.56) and reporting the correct dose and route of administration of epinephrine from 19% to 95% (RR:4.96; 95% CI: 2.26, 10.88). Residents also demonstrated increased identification of cardiovascular compromise in anaphylaxis, as well as often underrecognized gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms after the intervention. In an assessment evaluating longitudinal retention up to 15 months after the intervention, approximately 50% of those who responded to the longitudinal survey correctly recalled the dosing and route of administration of epinephrine for treating anaphylaxis.A brief educational session on anaphylaxis was successful in improving residents' short-term knowledge about diagnosis and treatment of anaphylaxis and may also impact long-term retention. DISCUSSION A brief educational session on anaphylaxis was successful in improving residents' short-term knowledge about diagnosis and treatment of anaphylaxis and may also impact long-term retention.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Hetal&amp;aulast=Mistry&amp;atitle=Assessing+Anaphylaxis%3A+Improving+Residents%27+Identification+of+a+Life-Threatening+Condition+via+a+Focused+Didactic+and+Case-Based+Discussion&amp;stitle=Rhode+Island+medical+journal+%282013%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Assessing+Anaphylaxis%3A+Improving+Residents%27+Identification+of+a+Life-Threatening+Condition+via+a+Focused+Didactic+and+Case-Based+Discussion&amp;volume=108&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=54&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Hetal&amp;aulast=Mistry&amp;atitle=Assessing+Anaphylaxis%3A+Improving+Residents%27+Identification+of+a+Life-Threatening+Condition+via+a+Focused+Didactic+and+Case-Based+Discussion&amp;stitle=Rhode+Island+medical+journal+%282013%29&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:&amp;title=Assessing+Anaphylaxis%3A+Improving+Residents%27+Identification+of+a+Life-Threatening+Condition+via+a+Focused+Didactic+and+Case-Based+Discussion&amp;volume=108&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=54&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

SHAPING THE FUTURE OF CHEMISTRY LEARNING: THE IMPACT OF PLAYFUL STRATEGIES AND DIGITAL TOOLS

Author: Álvarez, María Verónica Maila1; Alarcón, Elizabeth Yolanda Pérez2; Pozo-Rico, Teresa3; Gilar-Corbí, Raquel41 Universidad Central del Ecuador, Quito, Ecuador. E-mail mvmaila@uce.edu.ec Orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4139-76362 Universidad Central del Ecuador, Quito, Ecuador. E-mail: eyperez@uce.edu.ec Orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7739-59313 University of Alicante, Alicante, España. E-mail: teresa.pozo@ua.es Orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5849-46004 University of Alicante, Alicante, España. E-mail: raquel.gilar@ua.es Orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2209-4429

Publication info: Álvarez, María Verónica Maila; Alarcón, Elizabeth Yolanda Pérez; Pozo-Rico, Teresa; Gilar-Corbí, Raquel. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/shaping-future-chemistry-learning-impact-playful/docview/3276116009/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: Objective: This study examines the effectiveness of a methodological proposal that employs playful strategies through digital tools in the learning process of chemistry to improve the academic performance of first -semester students. Theoretical Framework: This research is grounded in theories of playful learning, gamification, and educational technology, highlighting the role of interactive and immersive methodologies in enhancing student motivation, knowledge retention, and overall academic success. Method: A quasi-experimental design with pre-test, post-test, and control group was employed to evaluate the effectiveness of the methodological proposal. The General Linear Model (GLM) for repeated measures was used for data analysis, with intra-subject factors (pre-test and post-test) and an inter-subject factor (experimental group vs. control group). Results and Discussion: The implementation of playful strategies positively influenced students' academic performance in certain areas of the course. However, not all units showed significant improvement, suggesting that the impact of these methodologies may vary depending on the content and context of the learning material. Research Implications: The study highlights the potential of playful strategies to promote not only better learning outcomes but also a more positive attitude toward education. Originality/Value: This research demonstrates the adaptability and effectiveness of playful learning and gamification in higher education settings, offering valuable insights for designing immersive learning experiences tailored to students' specific needs. Alternate abstract: Objetivo: Este estudo examina a eficácia de uma proposta metodológica que utiliza estratégias lúdicas por meio de ferramentas digitais no processo de aprendizagem de química para melhorar o desempenho acadêmico dos estudantes do primeiro semestre. Marco Teórico: Esta pesquisa baseia-se em teorias de aprendizagem lúdica, gamificação e tecnologia educacional, destacando o papel de metodologias interativas e imersivas em aumentar a motivação dos estudantes, a retenção do conhecimento e o sucesso acadêmico geral. Método: Foi utilizado um desenho quase-experimental com pré-teste, pós-teste e grupo de controle para avaliar a eficácia da proposta metodológica. O Modelo Linear Geral (MLG) para medidas repetidas foi empregado na análise dos dados, com fatores intra-sujeitos (pré-teste e pós-teste) e um fator inter-sujeitos (grupo experimental vs. grupo de controle). Resultados e Discussão: A implementação de estratégias lúdicas influenciou positivamente o desempenho acadêmico dos estudantes em algumas áreas do curso. No entanto, nem todas as unidades apresentaram melhora significativa, sugerindo que o impacto dessas metodologias pode variar dependendo do conteúdo e do contexto do material de aprendizagem. Implicações da Pesquisa: O estudo destaca o potencial das estratégias lúdicas para promover não apenas melhores resultados de aprendizagem, mas também uma atitude mais positiva em relação à educação. Originalidade/Valor: Esta pesquisa demonstra a adaptabilidade e a eficácia da aprendizagem lúdica e da gamificação em ambientes de ensino superior, oferecendo insights valiosos para projetar experiências de aprendizagem imersivas que atendam às necessidades específicas dos estudantes. Alternate abstract: Objetivo: Este estudio examina la efectividad de una propuesta metodológica que emplea las estrategias lúdicas a través de herramientas digitales en el proceso de aprendizaje de la químical para la mejora del rendimiento académico de los estudiantes de primer semestre. Marco Teórico: Esta investigación se basa en teorías de aprendizaje lúdico, gamificación y tecnología educativa, destacando el papel de las metodologías interactivas e inmersivas en aumentar la motivación de los estudiantes, la retención del conocimiento y el éxito académico general. Método: Se empleó un diseño cuasiexperimental con pretest, postest y grupo control para evaluar la efectividad de la propuesta metodológica. Para el análisis de datos se empeló el Modelo Lineal General (MLG) de medidas repetidas, con factores intra-sujetos (pretest y postest) y factor inter-sujetos (grupo experimental vs. grupo control). Resultados y Discusión: La implementación de estrategias lúdicas influyó positivamente en el rendimiento académico de los estudiantes en algunas áreas del curso. Sin embargo, no todas las unidades mostraron una mejora significativa, lo que sugiere que el impacto de estas metodologías puede variar dependiendo del contenido y del contexto del material de aprendizaje. Implicaciones de la Investigación: Se destaca el potencial de las estrategias lúdicas para promover no solo mejores resultados de aprendizaje, sino también una actitud más positiva hacia la educación. Originalidad/Valor: Esta investigación demuestra la adaptabilidad y la efectividad del aprendizaje lúdico y la gamificación en entornos de educación superior, ofreciendo valiosos conocimientos para diseñar experiencias de aprendizaje inmersivas que respondan a las necesidades específicas de los estudiantes.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Mar%C3%ADa+Ver%C3%B3nica&amp;aulast=%C3%81lvarez&amp;atitle=SHAPING+THE+FUTURE+OF+CHEMISTRY+LEARNING%3A+THE+IMPACT+OF+PLAYFUL+STRATEGIES+AND+DIGITAL+TOOLS&amp;stitle=Revista+de+Gest%C3%A3o+Social+e+Ambiental&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.24857%2Frgsa.v19n6-109&amp;title=SHAPING+THE+FUTURE+OF+CHEMISTRY+LEARNING%3A+THE+IMPACT+OF+PLAYFUL+STRATEGIES+AND+DIGITAL+TOOLS&amp;volume=19&amp;issue=6&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

From Surface to Deep Learning: Gamified Mobile Education for Subcutaneous and Intramuscular Injection Skills

Author: Tamer, Zeynep1    ; Kavuran, Esin1    1 Atatürk University, Department of Nursing Fundamentals, Faculty of Nursing, Erzurum, Turkey (GRID:grid.411445.1) (ISNI:0000 0001 0775 759X)

Publication info: Tamer, Zeynep; Kavuran, Esin. 

http://ezproxy.lb.polyu.edu.hk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/scholarly-journals/surface-deep-learning-gamified-mobile-education/docview/3259372473/se-2?accountid=16210

Abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of a game-based mobile application on nursing students’ skills in administering subcutaneous (SC) and intramuscular (IM) injections. Nursing education traditionally involves both theoretical and practical components. With the advent of digital technologies, innovative methods such as game-based learning have been introduced to enhance practical skills and knowledge retention in nursing education. This study explores the use of a mobile application designed to improve students’ competence in SC and IM drug administration. This was an experimental study conducted during the 2021–2022 academic year. It involved a study group of 64 students who received training through a simulation game system and a control group of 65 students who underwent traditional training methods. Data were collected using the Self-Demonstration Form, the Study Process Questionnaire, and the Skills Performance List for Subcutaneous and Intramuscular Administration. The study focused on assessing the impact of game-based learning on students’ performance and learning approaches. The study group showed significantly greater improvements in learning approaches and medication administration skills compared to the control group. Deep learning scores increased from 31.39 ± 6.23 to 45.05 ± 5.46 in the study group, versus 31.78 ± 5.68 to 37.02 ± 4.17 in the control group ( p  < 0.01). SC and IM administration scores improved significantly in the study group (SC: 22.50 ± 15.46 to 42.45 ± 11.66, p  = 0.015; IM: 27.75 ± 15.98 to 59.45 ± 12.95, p  < 0.001) compared to the control group. Scenario-based analyses also showed significant performance gains in the study group across all scenarios ( p  < 0.05). The HEM-SC-IM game-based mobile application proved effective in improving nursing students’ skills in administering SC and IM injections. The interactive and engaging nature of game-based learning provides a valuable educational experience, promoting deeper understanding and practical skills development. This study supports the integration of educational technology in nursing curricula to enhance learning outcomes.

Links: https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zeynep&amp;aulast=Tamer&amp;atitle=From+Surface+to+Deep+Learning%3A+Gamified+Mobile+Education+for+Subcutaneous+and+Intramuscular+Injection+Skills&amp;stitle=Medical+Science+Educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02323-w&amp;title=From+Surface+to+Deep+Learning%3A+Gamified+Mobile+Education+for+Subcutaneous+and+Intramuscular+Injection+Skills&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1431&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

https://julac-hkpu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/openurl/852JULAC_HKPU/852JULAC_HKPU:HKPU?sid=proquest&amp;auinit=Zeynep&amp;aulast=Tamer&amp;atitle=From+Surface+to+Deep+Learning%3A+Gamified+Mobile+Education+for+Subcutaneous+and+Intramuscular+Injection+Skills&amp;stitle=Medical+Science+Educator&amp;btitle=&amp;id=doi:10.1007%2Fs40670-025-02323-w&amp;title=From+Surface+to+Deep+Learning%3A+Gamified+Mobile+Education+for+Subcutaneous+and+Intramuscular+Injection+Skills&amp;volume=35&amp;issue=3&amp;date=2025&amp;spage=1431&amp;isbn=&amp;genre=article&amp;

ERIC Subject: Computer Simulation; Clinical Experience; Grade Point Average; Informed Consent; Control Groups; Influence of Technology; Multiple Choice Tests; Educational Methods; Learning Processes; College Faculty; Likert Scales; Academic Achievement; Measurement Techniques; Cognitive Style; Computer Assisted Instruction; Memorization; College Freshmen; Data Analysis; Item Analysis; Computer Software; Computer Use; Game Based Learning; Educational Games; Flow Charts; Content Validity

Subject: Students; Nursing education; Deep learning; Mobile communications networks; Performance evaluation; Games; Skills; Simulation; Educational objectives; Academic achievement; Participation; Knowledge; Design; Skill development; Confounding (Statistics); Gamification; Drug administration
